—When clients first come to the Child Support Agency, many of them are going through a very traumatic period in their lives and it is very hard for the Child Support Agency to be involved at that time. At the start-up of the Child Support Agency, it was always envisaged that the agency would handle the non-custodial parents and that the Department of Social Security, which pays out to custodial parents, would handle queries from the custodial parents. PARA.TAB: We also did not anticipate the rapid growth. The statistics are well worth having a look at. When the Child Support Agency was established in 1988, it started with 58 clients. Today that figure has risen to 293,000 and every week there are 2,800 applications. I doubt whether there is a government agency anywhere—certainly not in Australia and in few places in the world—that would have growth approaching that. In addition, every working day the Child Support Agency receives 8,500 telephone calls and 8,200 letters.

The Child Support Agency pays out an average of $51 a week for 240,000 Australian kids. Its collection rate, which is now 75 per cent of net liabilities or, if we measure it since 1988, a collection rate of 68 per cent of all debt, is by far the best in the world. TALK.START.PARA: —What does the member for Chifley say about that?

PARA.TAB: As I said, the agency often deals with emotional people and many people on the other end of the phone need help. TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: Under current legislation, people who receive compensation for an injury should reimburse the Commonwealth for Medicare and nursing home benefits which they have received in respect of that injury. However, the review of the relationship between compensation and health and community services programs found that many people receiving compensation designed to meet the full cost of injury-related medical and other care needs do not reimburse the Commonwealth. They `double-dip' by receiving free or heavily subsidised services funded by the Commonwealth, as well as compensation for the full costs of these services.

PARA.TAB: Double dipping can never be acceptable, because it means that the community pays twice for a service—once through insurance and again through Commonwealth funding. The current policy to prevent double dipping is not able to be implemented properly because of flaws in the legislation. According to the work of the review, it appears to be widely circumvented.

This main compensation bill and its cognate bills seek to address the problems with the existing legislation and ensure that the Commonwealth is reimbursed the equivalent of benefits that have been paid, as current policy requires. It is important to stop double dipping because it diverts limited resources away from injured people who have no alternative source of assistance, apart from Commonwealth programs.

The amendments will improve systems to identify compensation claimants and recipients, and to recover benefits paid prior to an award of compensation. The benefits covered by the bills are Medicare benefits, provided under the Health Insurance Act 1973, and nursing home benefits, provided under the National Health Act 1953. The new provisions will ensure that compensation claimants and recipients, insurers, and compensation payers are aware of their liabilities to the Commonwealth, where Medicare benefits and/or nursing home benefits have been paid to claimants before their compensation is payable. The bills are particularly targeted at lump sum compensation payments. Double dipping is generally not a problem under periodic payment schemes because expenses are reimbursed as they are incurred.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Identification of people who receive compensation

PARA.TAB: It is estimated that approximately 73,000 compensation cases are finalised each year, with many more than that number ongoing at any one time. To improve the identification of these cases, the main bill requires insurers and compensation payers to notify the Health Insurance Commission of details of claims lodged for compensation. They must also notify the commission of key events in their progress and of their finalisation.
While seeking to improve identification of compensation claimants and recipients, the new arrangements protect individuals' private information relating to their treatment histories.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Benefits paid prior to compensation becoming payable

PARA.TAB: Medicare and nursing home benefits paid to, or in respect of, a person because of their compensable injury up until compensation is payable will be recovered from the compensation payment. Where the amount of compensation is reduced because of contributory negligence, the amount of benefits to be recovered will be determined on the basis of the reduced compensation award.

Compensation claimants will be required to identify all services received in respect of the compensable injury prior to the compensation case being finalised. Insurers and compensation payers will then be notified by the Health Insurance Commission of the amount to be reimbursed to the Commonwealth. This will be done prior to the compensation amount being determined.

Although the debt will be the compensable person's, insurers or compensation payers will be liable to the Commonwealth for payment of the amount claimed from the compensation. Payment will be made by the insurer or compensation payer at the time compensation becomes payable. Given these arrangements, no appeals process against recoveries for past benefits is necessary because the claimant identifies the services in respect of the compensable injury and for which benefits have been paid. Claimants can then ensure that the amount to be paid to the Commonwealth is reflected in the terms of the compensation payment.

The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill 1994 is being introduced with this bill. The administration fee bill introduces a fee which will be charged to insurers or compensation payers where an amount of compensation has become payable. The fee will cover ongoing running costs of the new provisions, making the recovery process self-funding.

There is a two-tiered fee system. A $150 fee will apply to cases which are finalised within five years or less of the date of the accident, and a $300 fee will apply to cases finalised more than five years after that date. The higher fee for older cases reflects the higher cost associated with information storage and retrieval. It is envisaged that the higher fee for these cases may also encourage quicker resolution of compensation cases which would generally be to the advantage of the compensation claimant.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the National Health Act 1953

PARA.TAB: Some consequential amendments are required to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973. For example, an amendment is required to include administration of these bills as a function of the Health Insurance Commission.

Amendments are also required to the current provisions aimed at preventing double dipping in Medicare and nursing home benefits; that is, to section 18 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and section 59 of the National Health Act 1953, respectively, to reflect the new provisions.

Savings each year from these measures are estimated to be around $40 million. Costs will be approximately $9.4 million in 1994-95 and subsequent years. Running costs will be fully offset by the administration fee.

Legislative changes to prevent double dipping in relation to the cost of medical services are of great importance to the government. There can be no doubt that double dipping adds to the cost of Medicare and nursing home benefits. It also creates inequities between people with acquired disabilities who receive compensation and those who do not. The government is committed to establishing a simple, fair system to ensure that people with disabilities who receive compensation contribute towards the cost of care which they have already received. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) CARE CHARGES BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill accompanies the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994. In effect, it duplicates those provisions of the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994 which relate to the recovery of Medicare and nursing home benefits which have been paid to a compensable person prior to compensation becoming payable.

The need for this duplication arises from the fact that in some circumstances the recovery provisions in the main compensation bill could be construed to be a form of taxation. In case of this interpretation, the provisions must also appear in a separate bill. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) ADMINISTRATION FEE BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill accompanies the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill 1994. It provides for an administration fee to be paid by insurers and compensation payers when an amount becomes payable to the Commonwealth to recover benefits paid to or in respect of a compensable person.

The fee will fund the running costs of administering the package of measures to improve the identification of compensation claimants and recipients and the recovery of Medicare and nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of a compensable person and which were paid prior to the compensation becoming payable. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: HEALTH AND OTHER SERVICES (COMPENSATION) (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill is an integral part of the package to improve the identification of compensation claimants and recipients and the recovery of Medicare and nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of compensable people. The bill includes amendments that are required to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 arising from the new provisions. For example, administration of the other three bills in this package must be included as a function of the Health Insurance Commission. The commission will act as the Commonwealth's agent for the Department of Human Services and Health in relation to recoveries of nursing home benefits in compensation cases.

Amendments are also required to section 18 of the Health Insurance Act 1973 and section 59 of the National Health Act 1953 to reflect the new provisions. These sections will continue to operate after the commencement of the new provisions, if a person seeks Medicare or nursing home benefits in respect of the injury for which he or she has been awarded compensation. I commend this bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I felt it was important to set the record straight, since we had so many inaccuracies this morning from the member for Mackellar. The bills before the House are designed to introduce measures to address the problem of double dipping in the federal government's health and community services programs by people who have received compensation for injuries they have sustained. Double dipping occurs when a person in receipt of a compensation payment, to cover medical and other care costs relating to a compensatable injury, does not reimburse the cost of the services already provided through health programs subsidised by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: Double dipping hits the wider community through taxpayer-funded or subsidised programs and through increased insurance premiums. People are paying more for their health care costs because the Commonwealth is covering a person for the medical expenses incurred as a result of an injury and for which compensation can later be gained but when that person gains a compensation payment for that injury he or she is then not paying back the Commonwealth for the costs of those medical services that have been provided. So such people are getting two bites at the cherry. They get free medical services provided through Medicare and then get paid, through their insurance, for the provision of those free medical services or subsidised medical services.

The measures contained in this package of bills will save the government an estimated $40 million, although it will cost $10 million to administer, due to data storage requirements and the resources needed for identification and recovery measures. These savings will free up funds for use in other areas of the health portfolio, allowing these additional funds to be spent on things such as public hospitals, nursing homes, aged care facilities and pharmaceutical benefits, et cetera—all of which will benefit the wider Australian community. I am pleased that the shadow minister has indicated that the opposition will be supporting all of the legislation bar the imposition of the administration charge. I will talk about that shortly.

The need for this legislation is highlighted by the number of factors which show an alarming number of compensated people are double dipping into the health system. Much of the substance of this legislation has been borne out of recommendations contained in a discussion paper called Compensation and Commonwealth Health and Community Services Programs, released in June 1993. It was then distributed to all of the people involved in insurance and compensation payments. There were great opportunities for the industry to be involved in this process. It knew what the Commonwealth was about. It knew what the intentions of the Commonwealth were in producing this legislation to respond to the issues raised in this discussion paper.

The review found that double dipping was a widespread practice with significant financial implications for the Commonwealth's programs. Although it is difficult to calculate, the discussion paper found that over $700 million is spent annually on treatment costs for compensatable people. This figure includes only workers compensation board and motor vehicle accident cases. The treatment includes hospital, nursing home, and medical and community health service outlays, with hospital costs comprising 34.2 per cent and medical costs 38.7 per cent of the total.

The need for this legislation is very hard to deny, and I think that is recognised by the opposition. The discussion paper identified that over 50 per cent of all inquiries to the Health Insurance Commission from solicitors just prior to settlement of a case were the first time that the Health Insurance Commission knew that there was a case pending for compensation. A Health Insurance Commission survey in 1988 found that about 700 letters per month were received from solicitors seeking data for use in settling compensation claims. Over half of these were the first indication to Medicare that such a claim existed. With statistics like these, it is anticipated that this package of bills will provide an effective process for greater identification and recovery from cases. The discussion paper went on to comment:

SPEECH.PARA: Incentives for patients are to not disclose compensatable status when a lump sum settlement is concluded, when service costs have been redeemed under a statutory scheme and when the right to compensation is in doubt, as is the case in many pending common law motor vehicle cases.

Clearly, this double-dipping process has been a drain on Australia's health resources for a number of years. In 1980 a study of compensation recipients by consultants Neave and Howell found that eight years after receiving compensation, about half of those still alive required medical treatment for their injuries in the preceding year, and nearly 21 per cent had 10 or more accident related visits to a doctor or physiotherapist.

PARA.TAB: The findings of the discussion paper released last year mirrored this earlier survey. This is a massive double drain on public and private health insurance funds which is not acceptable to most fair-minded Australians. Theoretically, these accident related costs should be met from the damages payments that were awarded. However, there are shortcomings in the existing legislation. The proposed legislation will enable us to find out about these cases and to in fact pursue those funds that are owed back to the Commonwealth.

Compensated accident victims are required to indicate this fact to Medicare and private insurers and are then ruled ineligible for benefits. In reality, this group have not been meeting the full costs of their treatment and are still receiving the full form of subsidy from the Commonwealth. In general terms, this is not because of any intentional deceit or questionable honesty on the part of the compensatable people, but rather a lack of information and knowledge by those parties involved about how they should go about the process of repaying the Commonwealth. Again, as the discussion paper noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The Health Insurance Act contains no relevant powers to require information about compensation. It contains no provisions for data linkage or the exchange of information between compensation authorities or providers and Commonwealth authorities.

This legislation clarifies the situation by requiring all insurers and other compensation payers to notify the Health Insurance Commission of all claims lodged for compensation for personal injury where liability is not accepted at the outset. It will also require payers of compensation to provide notification of all settlements and judgments in personal injury cases.

PARA.TAB: The legislation provides for the recovery of all Medicare and nursing home benefits paid up to the time compensation is payable for services provided to a compensatable person because of the injury. The Commonwealth will recover these amounts directly from the insurer on the occasion of settlement or judgment. Where contributory negligence has the effect of reducing the amount of compensation awarded, a proportional recovery of benefits will be allowed. It should be noted that these requirements will not impact negatively in any way on the rights and entitlements of the person seeking compensation at the time of judgment and settlement. They will seek only to recover and prevent compensatable persons from gaining dual access to federal health services in future years.

To ensure the effective operation of the main thrust of this legislation, this package of bills includes the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Care Charges Bill, which has been drafted in case the judiciary interprets the recovery of these benefits to be a form of taxation. The constitution requires taxation matters to be isolated in an act, hence we have this particular bill.

The package also includes the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Administration Fee Bill, which provides the administrative framework for this package of measures. The opposition has indicated its intention to oppose this bill. Its main feature is the existence of an administration charge on insurers to meet the operating costs of the improved identification and recovery mechanisms. The fee applies to every case where there is an amount payable to the Commonwealth under the new legislation. It becomes payable on the occasion of a case being finalised.

A two-tier fee structure will operate—$150 for cases finalised within five years of injury, and $300 for claims finalised after this period. This fee differential arises out of the need to store data on long-term claims for longer periods than is usual.

Also included in the package is the Health and Community Services (Compensation) (Consequential Amendments) Bill. This bill makes necessary consequential amendments to the National Health Act 1953 and the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow minister commented that there was a lack of consultation in the preparation of this bill. However, this matter was outlined in quite extensive detail in the review of the compensation of Commonwealth health and community service programs, which was released as a discussion paper in June 1993 and was forwarded to all those insurance companies. Therefore, they did have the opportunity to put forward their views, and they knew that the Commonwealth was working on this matter. The paper ensured that insurers knew that the Commonwealth was seeking to address this problem in this way. Any legislative measures that needed to be developed to address the widespread practice of double dipping, which we are seeking to address today, were going to be impossible to frame without imposing new requirements on the industry.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit inconsistent of the opposition to argue in this place, as it consistently does, that the Commonwealth should be seeking to reduce its costs, that it should be seeking to balance the budget and to reduce the deficit; yet where there is a legitimate process contained in legislation which seeks to recover from industry the costs of a measure which the opposition knows the industry should be meeting but has not been meeting to date, it seeks to oppose it.

It is quite a legitimate process for the government to require the insurance industry to cover the costs of the administration of these new measures and it is not something that the insurance companies would not have been expecting. Of course, they are going to write letters to the member for Mackellar saying, `Yes, we think it is dreadful we are going to have to pay this charge.' I would not expect insurance companies to say anything less. But they know that it is quite reasonable, they know that it is quite legitimate, they know that it is not an unreasonable fee.

The government has a legitimate responsibility to ensure that the industry meets the costs of recovering this process, recovering the $40 million that is involved per annum. This recovery process will ensure that the Commonwealth has access to additional funds that can help it meet its other requirements in the health and human services portfolio.

The government is pleased to be able to bring this legislation forward and we look forward to the opposition's support for the package of bills, apart from the one bill to which it has indicated its opposition. I again say that I think the opposition is being totally inconsistent in its opposition to this bill when compared with the statements that it makes in this place from time to time regarding the requirements of the government to meet its financial obligations and to reduce the deficit. This package of bills will achieve significant justice and end the double dipping process that has been occurring, and I urge the support of the House for all of the legislation before us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of bills are being debated cognately at this time. I want to concentrate my remarks this morning on the main bill in the package—the Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill. The reason I rise in this debate is related to part 2, division 2, clauses 9 and 10 of the main bill. Division 2 relates to the recovery of costs in respect of compensable persons, as defined, who have received residential care in a nursing home funded by a Commonwealth nursing home benefit. This relates to my responsibility as shadow minister for aged care.

PARA.TAB: In general, compensable persons affected by division 2 will be residents in nursing homes who are, in the most part, younger than 60 years of age. According to the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare report Australia's welfare 1993: services and assistance, in 1992 there were 2,426 residents of nursing homes under the age of 60. I assume that today the current number of such residents would be very similar to that of 1992.

In discussing the cost of their care we should reflect on the fact that these people reside in nursing homes because of physical infirmity due to injury, illness or disability. Many have active minds living in a badly damaged or disabled body. The two most common reasons for a younger person having to be in a nursing home are multiple sclerosis or a motor car accident. All things considered, these people have a difficult and tragic existence.

While it is not the scope of the debate here today, while mentioning this issue I will reflect on the fact that the needs of younger people in nursing homes may not be, or are not, the same as older people in nursing homes. It is a sad commentary that in this country we do not provide specific facilities to cater for the needs of younger people in nursing homes. These people by and large are able to make a choice: they could choose to be in a mainstream nursing home or they could choose to be in a nursing home which caters specifically for the needs of younger people. Today they do not have that choice.

Before making specific comments on the main bill, I would like to reiterate that the federal coalition is as keen as the government to close off avenues for double dipping of health benefits wherever they may arise. This naturally includes circumstances such as those anticipated in this legislation: namely, compensation, damages or other financial settlements that have been paid to or on behalf of people who have sustained an injury or suffered from a disease which is subject to compensation.

I note that the explanatory memorandum for this bill explains that part 2, division 2 is intended to apply to nursing homes benefits the same cost recovery provisions that part 1, division 1 of the bill applies to Medicare benefits. I also note that the intention of division 1, which the nursing home provisions are intended to mirror, is to ensure that a compensable person does not enjoy the financial benefit of some form of financial settlement which covers medical service costs incurred under the Medicare scheme. I am advised that this closes off a loophole in the Health Insurance Act, and as such it is timely.

In looking at the similar provisions proposed for nursing home benefits in division 2, I have some concerns. These concerns are not, as I have just indicated, with the principle or policy of preventing double dipping but with some of the practical issues that arise in attempting to address these issues through this legislation. My two particular concerns come under two broad headings: first, the relationship of clause 9 and clause 10 of the main bill and the National Health Act—in particular, section 59 of that act; and, secondly, some of the logistical problems I anticipate in trying to give effect to the broad intent of this legislation in the context of a nursing home.

In making my comments, I have had a look at the 1993 discussion paper Compensation and Commonwealth health and human services programs. The paper, authored for the government compensation review by Mr Tom Brennan, contains proposals which are reflected in the outcomes of the review process. In preparing this legislation, I am assuming that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) and her advisers are endorsing Brennan's views. Yet, when looking at the main bill now before us, I cannot help thinking that they have somehow missed a point about the relationship between compensable persons, nursing home care and financial settlements.

Chapter 5 of the discussion paper makes the a few relevant observations: first, nursing homes are subsidised by the Commonwealth under the National Health Act 1953 and, second, section 59 of that act provides for preclusion from nursing home benefits, by reason of compensation and recovery of those benefits, when compensation is paid to a person who is receiving or has received residential care. As it stands, the catch with section 59 of the National Health Act is that it imposes a liability at the discretion of the minister, or her delegate, to repay nursing home benefits on the nursing home proprietor. This is because the proprietor, and not the nursing home resident, is the legal receiver of Commonwealth funding.
What Tom Brennan proposed, however, in his discussion paper—what I am assuming the government is taking up here—is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A . . . legislative scheme (which) would place liability on the participants in the compensation: first the insurer; second the compensation payer; and third the patient.
Brennan goes on:
By removing proprietors from the compensation recovery provisions the Commonwealth could enhance the prospect of proprietors identifying compensable patients.

This, in my reading at least, is what clauses 9 and 10 of the main bill set out to do. But this does not change the legal beneficiary relationship of the proprietor to the Commonwealth under the National Health Act. This will not change even though section 59 of that act will be amended to state that proprietors will not, as I read the consequential amendments, be liable to repay nursing home benefits prior to the making of a settlement, judgment or reimbursement arrangement after the day the present legislation comes into force.

PARA.TAB: While, therefore, the proposed consequential amendment to the National Health Act is intended to take proprietors out of the particular loop of liability as Brennan intended, proprietors still are the legal point of receipt for Commonwealth nursing home benefits. This seems to be a latent ambiguity which could create uncertainty for nursing home proprietors, if not actual financial detriment. The simple question I, therefore, put to the government is: just what thought has been given to the role of the nursing home proprietor and the new set of financial relationships covered by this legislation? I am not convinced at this time that the financial and operational interests of nursing home proprietors are protected adequately by this legislation. The coalition would appreciate some clarification of the future role for proprietors as it is envisaged by the government.

When regulations for the operation of this legislation are placed before the parliament we, on this side, will be scrutinising the small print very closely to ensure that proprietors, as much as persons paying or receiving financial rewards, are dealt with equally and fairly. I would not want to see, for example, a possible situation where nursing home proprietors are pressured financially if, for some reason, the Commonwealth cannot recover its nursing home benefit outlay from other parties.

The other concerns I would like to raise in this debate go to the likely effectiveness of processes and procedures which would implement the provisions of the main bill in the nursing home sector. Once again, I wonder whether the government has thought through its proposals in the light of everyday reality of nursing home funding practices. To give some very brief background, funding nursing home beds takes into account the following funding components as part of the basic nursing home benefit: firstly, the care aggregated module, CAM, which covers nursing and other personal care services. As members may be aware, there are different rates of CAM which are intended to reflect the degree of care required by each individual resident as assessed through what is known as the resident classification instrument.
Secondly, the standard aggregated module, SAM, which reimburses the nursing home on a dollar per bed basis for its overall general operating expenses, such as cooking and cleaning services.

Thirdly, other costs reimbursed expenditure, OCRE, which is a formula covering nursing homes for such special expenses as leave loadings and workers compensation. This expenditure, particularly CAM and SAM expenditure, is subjected by the government to checks and reviews. Most importantly, there are annual reconciliations of Commonwealth payments to nursing homes at the end of each financial year, and there are validations conducted by the Department of Human Services and Health of CAM and SAM expenditure of nursing homes. These validations are intended to ensure that the government and the taxpayers' funds are paid to nursing homes and are spent appropriately.

But validations are a problem for nursing homes and their operators, a problem which relates to the matters at hand before the House. This is because the present cumbersome nature of the CAM-SAM validation process is slow and ponderous. It is a process that is seriously disliked by the industry and it flies in the face of good management and good accounting practices. It should be noted that in 1994-95 validations are still taking place for expenditure incurred as long ago as 1986-87, with consequential funding adjustments being made to nursing home entitlements going back six to seven years.

In terms of the operating realities of nursing homes, this is ancient history but the fact remains that nursing homes can and do find themselves owing money to the government arising from validated funding adjustments relating to operational expenses many years previously. This is not the place to debate the rights or wrongs of the validation process, but what I am endeavouring to show here is that the final per bed CAM and SAM costs of nursing home care will not, in all likelihood, be known for many years, as many as seven or eight years from the time that expenditure is incurred.

In his second reading speech, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence (Mr Bevis), who is at the table, suggested that these bills would enable precise costs already incurred to be factored into subsequent compensation payments or other financial settlements. On the basis of the matters I have outlined, I cannot share the parliamentary secretary's confidence on this point. Taking validated expenditure into account, if a compensated person's nursing costs need to be adjusted after a recovery is made by the Commonwealth, would the person be entitled to a credit if one was found due, or would he or she be subject to further payments six or seven years down the road?

I would therefore suggest, for the consideration of the Minister for Human Services and Health and her parliamentary secretary, that any regulations, guidelines or directions made under part 1, division 2 of the main bill refer to validated expenditure and not just the raw estimate of nursing home benefit expenditure for a compensable person receiving residential care. This is a difficult problem, even allowing for the timelags inherent, for instance, in seeking a personal injury award through common law processes.

Such delays in cost reckoning or in the receipt and calculation of damages or other financial settlements can lead conceivably to financial detriment being suffered by the types of parties identified in this legislation or by nursing home proprietors. Once again, it is important for the government to ensure that guidelines and processes under this legislation work fairly and equitably for all concerned while seeking to achieve the broad purposes of this legislation.

In closing, I would like to make a brief point about consultation. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) has also had something to say about this from her perspective. In preparing for this debate, I consulted with a senior and deeply knowledgeable officer in a nursing home industry organisation about the implications of these bills. Those consultations reinforced my broad reservations about the possible orientation of part 1, division 2 of this main bill. This officer, who should know, was asked whether his organisation was consulted by the Minister for Human Services and Health, her predecessor, or the Department of Human Services and Health in the preparation of this legislation. It will be no surprise to the House to learn that the answer was a decided no.

Time and time again in my portfolio area I come across actions of a government which invariably insists that it knows best, a government that tells the aged care industry what to do, even though proprietors and managers have a great wealth of experience to share with government. This may be the Labor way, but it may result in legislation which, like this, can look good on paper but can run into difficulties when the time comes to implement it. I can assure the House that lack of consultation will not be a feature of the next coalition government.

Finally, I would like to make a comment following on from the member for Mackellar's comment that neither the minister nor her parliamentary secretary saw fit to introduce this bill. I have concerns about this bill. I have tried to bring them here in a constructive and cooperative way. The concerns relate to how this bill may actually function in operation. I could have tried to move amendments. I could have seen that when it finally gets to the Senate it goes to an inquiry, that it gets held up. I have not done that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might have to.

—I may have to do it yet. The honourable member is right. But the simple courtesy of the minister or her parliamentary secretary has not been shown to me or this House by their coming in here and at least listening to the debate on their bill. This House operates largely by consent, far more than the general public would ever realise. That consent relies on courtesies and conventions. —The Health and Other Services (Compensation) Bill and related bills obviously address a very serious issue. The matter of double dipping costs the government and taxpayers, so it is right that the general drift of what is being presented to the House receives my support. The problems are apparently quite widespread. A review in 1992 revealed this quite clearly. Again, it has taken all this time to get some correcting legislation to the House. That is disappointing.

PARA.TAB: The bills attempt, by my understanding, to address the issue by the development of improved systems to identify compensation claimants firstly and then to provide some teeth in recovery mechanisms of moneys that should rightly be directed to health, particularly to Medicare, thus saving the government an estimated $40 million or $50 million per year. I understand from the legislation that the fee to be charged for claims finalised within five years of the date of injury will be $150; for those claims settled five years after the date of injury, it will be around about $300. There is absolutely no doubt that these charges will subsequently have an impact on the premiums charged by insurance companies for coverage by their disability insurance—absolutely no doubt at all. Yet we have not had presented to us in this House for any consideration at all any kind of impact statement that has at least some sort of assessment of what that impact will be.

This is completely improper. I am certainly not happy with it. I stand with my other colleagues on this side of the House in opposing particularly that bill which imposes an administrative charge. I am also concerned that, with the premiums for disability insurance—and I use as an example the pressure that is currently being applied to the health insurance industry itself which has been created by the dramatic exodus from private insurance companies which has occurred; over the last 12 months that exodus has numbered in the order of 300,000 Australian families—and with fewer participants in private health insurance, the pressure on premiums is immense and increasing. Over the last 10 years there has been a dramatic decline in the number of Australians who are prepared to fund their own health insurance. It is not just the fall in the number of people who are members of the private health insurance system but the changing profile of those who remain in it. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been speaking on the bill. Opposition contributors to this debate have argued that the government should not increase the cost of private insurance through the administration charge in the legislation. If the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) had been here earlier, he would have understood that by listening to the contribution of the honourable member for Mallee.

PARA.TAB: The coalition cannot have it both ways. It cannot embrace a $40 million annual saving on the federal budget and also complain about an increase in private costs. There is no magic pudding in the health sector. There is no way public costs can be reduced without it having some impact on private costs. That is the point I make. It is a simple point. A first-year university student would understand these matters but they seem to be beyond the grasp of the shadow spokesperson; the member for Mallee; and, by his point of order, the right honourable member for New England.

This is good legislation because it will make an important saving in the federal budget. It addresses the question of double-dipping, which occurs when a person receives a compensation payment to cover medical and other care costs for an injury but does not reimburse the Commonwealth for the cost of services he or she has already received through programs subsidised by the Commonwealth. It is good legislation. It is quite comprehensive legislation, in that it seeks to make a number of amendments to the National Health Act 1953, the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973 and the Health Insurance Act 1973.

Let me respond to some of the other issues raised by the honourable member for Mackellar. She raised the question, as did other contributors, as to why the insurance industry was not consulted about the new provisions. Let me provide the answer to that question. The new provisions arise from the findings of a discussion paper entitled Compensation and Commonwealth health and community services programs published in June 1993 by the Review of the Relationship between Compensation and Health and Community Services Programs. This paper was sent out to the insurance industry and others, and submissions were received on the policy issues.

There has been substantial consultation. A discussion paper was circulated and absorbed by the industry, and submissions were sent back. The review found that double dipping is widespread, with significant financial implications for Commonwealth programs. Any legislative measures developed to address such a widespread practice were going to be impossible to frame without imposing new requirements on the industry. The shadow minister is always seeking the best of both worlds. She wants tighter scrutiny of national budgets and savings for the taxpayer but she wants there to be no impact on the industry she seeks to defend.

The legislative framework of the double-dipping provisions is the most straightforward possible. It balances the interests of insurers, people involved in compensation payments and the taxpayers generally. It is difficult in these circumstances to see how consultation could have assisted in this phase any more than it did. I do not think the honourable member for Mackellar in her remarks contributed anything positive as to how the consultation could have been further enhanced.

Opposition speakers have raised the question of the effect of the new provisions on no fault compensation schemes, such as statutory workers compensation. Under the new provisions, any Medicare or nursing home benefits paid to or in respect of a person up until he or she is accepted as eligible for compensation under statutory no fault schemes have to be reimbursed to the Commonwealth by the schemes. Under existing legislation, the Commonwealth should already be reimbursed for any benefits that were paid prior to acceptance of the compensation claims, except that the statutory schemes reimburse the compensable person for costs incurred up until his or her compensation claim is accepted and then the person involved should reimburse the Commonwealth for any benefits that were paid. That fully answers the concerns of opposition members.

Another question raised was: what is the effect on state and territory statutory compensation schemes? The creation and operation of statutory compensation schemes relating to injuries suffered by persons in any state is essentially a matter of state law. The double-dipping legislation does not attempt to impact in any direct way on the operation of state or territory compensation schemes. The legislation encompasses compensation paid under Commonwealth, state and territory statutory schemes as well as common law damages. However, the effect on statutory schemes is expected to be minimal. The reason is that, in general, statutory compensation schemes pay the medical and other care costs of the injured person as they are incurred from the time that the person's claim for compensation is accepted. This means that, in most statutory scheme cases, there will be no recoveries of Medicare or nursing home benefits to be made under the legislation.

It should also be noted that, under the double-dipping legislation, the majority of statutory scheme cases will have to be notified to the Health Insurance Commission. Only those claims which are not accepted for periodic payments within six months of the claim being made will have to be notified. Very few cases fall into this category.

The question has been raised—it has been central to the contribution of the opposition—as to whether or not the new provisions will force insurance premiums to increase. In the longer term, there may be some upward pressure on compensation settlements as they more accurately reflect the true costs of injury. The $40 million per annum saving has been calculated on the basis of 73,000 cases a year being affected by these provisions. That is an average recovery of approximately $550 for each case. This is unlikely to place much upward pressure on premiums. There certainly will not be any dramatic increase in premium costs.

The government can be satisfied that the saving it makes in its budget is worth while. It should be embraced by the opposition, which should understand that a saving of this nature in the public sector which ends double dipping is good public policy. The new provisions will have minimal effect on statutory schemes, such as workers compensation schemes, because they provide for reimbursement of expenses as they are incurred.

A further question that has been raised is whether or not these provisions create new bureaucracies funded at the expense of the insurance industry. The insurance industry is a multi-billion dollar industry in Australia. The cost of administering these provisions is approximately $10 million a year, with a staffing requirement of 156 officers in Health Insurance Commission offices around Australia.

Double dipping in relation to health and community services programs is estimated to cost the Australian taxpayer at least $40 million a year. Double dipping cannot be acceptable because the community in effect pays twice: firstly, through taxpayer funded or subsidised programs and, secondly, through insurance premiums. The central point of this package of bills now before the House is to tidy up the way in which these insurance and compensation arrangements have been made around Australia, to make sure there is no double burden on the taxpayer and to make sure that, if the taxpayer pays once with regard to compensation arrangements, those costs will be recouped by the Health Insurance Commission. It is a very effective reform. I would have thought it would have been embraced wholeheartedly by the honourable member for Mackellar.

She introduced the very difficult private health insurance reforms and got effective competition into that industry for the first time.

Then there is the COAG agenda. On top of all this, the shadow minister, who was not invited to the Liberal Party party last night, as she mentioned earlier—
