TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity, as the Senate has not returned the legislation for which this chamber is now waiting, to return to the defence white paper 1994. It seems to me that many issues arise out of the defence white paper and in the few minutes that are available to me I would like to address a few of those.

PARA.TAB: One of the areas in which Labor has failed the country miserably is defence. Successive defence white papers have outlined expectations for the amount of money that is to be allocated. There has been a glossy publication and a failure to fund the aspirations that that paper prescribes. Significantly, this white paper has reduced the amount of money to be provided and, we think, the expectations.

The tragedy is that in the opening part of the defence white paper the government has, without doubt, set out the regional environment in which Australia must look at its defence. In doing so, it has set down what I think we all accept is the enhanced responsibility the Australian Defence Force has as we move towards the year 2000, to work cooperatively with the nations of our region to try to ensure that, if there should be an emerging threat, Australia would be able to play some important role.

The statement does not at that stage but at a later stage refer to the defence role in peacekeeping. One of my concerns is that, having spoken about peacekeeping—I will come back to the funding of it in a moment—and having spoken of that regional role in defence, it then reverts to what I regard as the long since flawed conception that Professor Paul Dibb first enunciated: we should really worry predominantly about low level attacks on this nation of ours alone.

The structure of the Australian Defence Force in relation to attacking those low level defence threats has in one sense, I think, focused the attention of the Defence Force on a conceivable threat. But that focus is not, in my view, a realistic possibility. Indeed, in each of the successive Kangaroo exercises it has been apparent that the real deterrent to a low level threat is the police force and, particularly, the police forces of remote areas of Western Australia or the Northern Territory.

Even as far as the landing of refugees in their boats is concerned, we have already seen circumstances where those arrivals have walked downtown, found a telephone booth and rung up the local police to find out what they are going to do. When you hear of those circumstances, you realise that the main way you combat that low level defence threat, against which this white paper still seems to want the defence force oriented, is by ensuring that the Australian police forces, at the state and federal levels, have a capacity to deal with it and, of course, to work in conjunction with Customs, Coastguard and others to ensure that, if there should be some type of an intrusion on Australia's shores, there is a capacity to respond to it.

While the opening chapter of the defence white paper embraces that regional concept, I believe the relationship between the old Dibb theory, which seems to preoccupy most of the objectives of the Defence Force, and the rest of the white paper is flawed. I think it is very easy to identify the other failings of the Labor government.

The second worry I have is that successively over the years the government has not got right the defence equipment, on which it has been spending a large amount of the defence vote. Not only has it not got it right; it has used the money it has been given to re-equip the Defence Force to the detriment of providing the high training and maintenance of the morale of the three uniformed services. I am most concerned that, as we look at the Australian Defence Force today, expert and brilliant though many of the aspects of it are, the morale in a number of the services has never been so low. That applies particularly to the Royal Australian Air Force and to elements of the Royal Australian Navy.

I identify that at a time when the government, within this white paper, is still giving a lot of emphasis to what I see as some of the wrong priorities in re-equipping the Defence Force. I do not believe enough has been done to combat the inadequacies which are leading to an erosion of morale. That morale is absolutely critical if we are going to ask people to lay down their lives for the sake of the country. Underneath every commitment of a person in uniform is a fundamental and possible contingency which each might face. I will come back in a moment to what we should do about it and how we should go about it.

Let me revert now to re-equipment. The first area of my concern with Labor's planning has been its objective in trying to buy flogged off equipment, such as HMAS Westralia. Westralia is a very good example of a ship that had been just about worn down by the British before we bought it. It cost a fortune to put her into place, and she is still nowhere near as effective as HMAS Success. We have now done exactly the same thing. We have acquired, after considerable political duress from the United States, two vessels from the United States navy. Leaving aside the debacle of the government's mishandling of the situation—in that it did not register that there is both an administration and a legislature in the United Nations, so it did not set about trying to ensure that the United States Congress agreed with the sale—the sale consisted of two vessels that, in my view, are going to cost the Australian navy dearly before it has what it seeks. It would have been far better to have built those vessels in Australia. It certainly would have been far better if we had not bought ships that were just about worn out.

I turn to another aspect of the Defence Force that is talked about in relation to the army: the replacement of the APCs, the M113s. It is of real concern that we still have vessels that are grossly uncomfortable for the people who travel in them. If we are going to use such vessels in the tropics, they should not be ones that are particularly uncomfortable. The armour is too light for modern weapons; yet we are talking about upgrading them. What we should be doing is moving towards re-equipment by designing a vessel for the conditions which—if it is to be the white paper parameters—the white paper parameters have established. I do not believe we have done that.

The LAV vehicle is not suitable. We bought a Canadian vehicle designed to operate in the Northern Hemisphere, where it is cold. We want something that can operate either in the tropics or in the northern part of Australia. The LAV vehicle and the M113s, the APCs, are not intended, nor are they designed, for those purposes. When the coalition government was in office, we started planning for Project Waler. Project Waler was designed to enable Australia to develop and design its own equipment to meet the requirements of the Australian Defence Force. In my view, it would be far better if we reinstated Project Waler to ensure that we have a vehicle designed to meet Australian conditions.

There is a whole range of other instances where the government seems quite intent on going out and getting equipment off the shelf from other countries instead of trying to design, develop and manufacture equipment here. Sure, quite a deal has been done to try to manufacture equipment in Australia by way of the Anzac vessels and the new Collins class submarines. But in my view neither of those is ideally suited to Australian conditions, but that is another argument. The concern I have is that they both should have been designed in Australia.

I am quite fascinated to see that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is embracing the idea of trying to sell submarines to the Koreans. He should know that one of the troubles of the submarine design is that it is not ours; it belongs to the Swedes. We have the technical capacity in Australia to design things ourselves. Why has this government made our designs subservient to those acquired from Europeans, Americans or somebody else? The Prime Minister pretends to assert Australian sovereignty. All he does is subject Australia to acquiring designs from somebody else.

Sure we can take the advice of consultants, if need be. We can accept assistance from universities, academics and others who might help to develop designs suitable to Australia, but every one of the major pieces of equipment that has been manufactured in Australia in recent years has come from overseas, including even the Steyr rifle. What the devil is the government about? We built the Owen gun during World War II. Why can we not build a rifle for today? I think it is an absolute disgrace that this government has not tried to encourage design capability within this country instead of just looking at manufacturing.

I turn to the rest of the white paper and a number of other areas that worry me. I think it is important that we look to addressing the morale problem which I identified earlier. Let us look at the Royal Australian Air Force. I am delighted to see that we will upgrade the F111C and that the F111G that has been acquired from the United States is now apparently coming into operation. We still have no airborne early warning system. Without that, we are not in a position to be able to direct those aircraft onto target. It is no use saying that Jindalee, as it is being developed and extended, will be able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was that designed?

—Jindalee was designed, in part, in Australia from an American base. The problem is that without the Americans we would not have been able to get Jindalee off the ground, which is a great tragedy. At the same time, Jindalee is Australian to a greater degree than American. The problem is that, without the capability of airborne command and control systems, the capacity of our FA18s or F111s is significantly reduced. While yet again there is talk of acquiring them at some future time, the priority given to them, to my mind, is not adequate.

PARA.TAB: I think it would have been appropriate in terms of our peacekeeping commitments to have looked at what we are going to do with the 707s, which are used now for both refuelling and transport operations within the Defence Force and for VIP operations. With their modern engines, they are not suited to landing. We have talked about airport noise at Mascot. One thing people forget is that modern aircraft engines have improved significantly and that today the level of aircraft noise is significantly lower than it used to be. Our 707s are very good examples of that. They cannot now be used in a lot of modern airports because the noise level is too high. I would have liked the defence white paper, in looking at the future of the air force, to have identified that we need to replace those 707s. It could have looked at refuelling. It could have looked at an aircraft which would also have been suitable for command and control, for an AWAC type capability. I think that should be given a higher priority than the defence white paper has given it.

What worries me is that, in the nature of the defence white paper, there are problems in terms of budget availability. I do not accept that two per cent of the budget or of gross domestic product, with the idea of being able to top up the vote every time we have a peacekeeping obligation, is the way to go.

I would far preferred to have seen that peacekeeping obligation put into the defence vote. There is certainly going to be an ongoing obligation by Australia, which we all support. I would have liked to have seen that vote increased to the point where we might have been able to undertake, for example, the acquisition of that replacement for the 707s that are now used for the transport of VIPs and refuelling. We would have had a new generation of aircraft there which would have given us that command and control function to which I referred.

One other area I briefly want to refer to is defence science and technology. There has been a tremendous effort undertaken in that area over the years. I notice that two per cent of the defence vote is allocated to that. I am still worried about the extent to which that still seems to be very much a poor relation to the rest of the Defence Force. I think that has not been given enough emphasis in the white paper.

I am equally concerned that there does not seem to be enough of a recognition of the role of the reserves. The new 5th Infantry Battalion, unfortunately, is only given a three- to four-year time frame. That, to my mind, should be accelerated in line with the peacekeeping report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to at least two years. I do not believe it should incorporate a company of reservists, for that is at about a quarter of its strength.

The defence white paper does embrace some excellent concepts. Regrettably, I do not believe the funding is there to meet them, nor do I believe the government is looking at Australia's overall civilian capability in the way that it might to enable Australia to undertake the level of defence that might be necessary in the forthcoming years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always respected the approach of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) to defence, because I know that over a large number of years he has had a great deal of interest in defence matters and has served this country as a Minister for Defence. Nevertheless, despite that respect, I must draw his attention to the fact that in the 1993 election he was part of the coalition which campaigned for a $400 million cut to the defence budget.

PARA.TAB: It must be said that we on this side of the House are often bemused when the government is attacked for failing to spend sufficient funds on any one particular program. It is difficult to take the call for an increased defence vote from the honourable gentleman seriously when his own party has supported quite savage cuts to the defence vote. Having said that, it must also be realised that, when the opposition calls for massive cuts to the expenditure base of Australia, across a wide variety of areas it is in fact calling for an increase in expenditure.

The simple reality of the defence vote is that it is dependent upon the revenue base of the country and the economic demand on the expenditure side. Defence is one of those aspects in Australian expenditure which must be taken into account in the overall budget perspective. This government has a very proud record on defence. It is one which I am not ashamed of. My own interest lies very heavily in this area because the major army base at Puckapunyal is located in my electorate. For those who do not know, that is the home of the Australian Armoured Corps.

The corps was established during the First World War and was one of the very early armoured brigades that the Australian Army had. Its history throughout its formation period has been a very proud one. Even today at Puckapunyal they celebrate the Cambrai Day parade, which recognises the efforts of the Australian Armoured Corps in the Western theatre of the Second World War. As most members are aware, the major vehicle in the Armoured Corps today is the Leopard tank—a German tank—which we acquired some 20 years ago now. It is, in anyone's language, an ageing tank, yet it is still with its 105 millimetre cannon and its fairly modern firepower systems a most effective armoured weapon.

I listened with interest to the right honourable member for New England's attack on the government's armoured program. He seems to forget that the M113, whilst an old armoured personnel carrier, has through Australian design and Australian technology been varied for use in Australian conditions. For example, the M113 comes in various forms in Australia as a result of Australian design. There are a number of M113 armoured vehicles which have a scorpion turret. That carries a 75 pound cannon, which is a very effective close range support cannon in infantry actions. There are other M113s which have had similar firepower systems adapted to the basic armoured personnel carrier systems.

It is wrong to say that Australia has not been adaptive and has not used its own design and its own technological processes to adapt different design systems from overseas to Australian circumstances. It really is quite ludicrous for any member of the opposition to suggest that the six new Collins submarines being built in Australia are not suitable for Australian conditions. I was quite bemused to hear the right honourable gentleman suggest that. Does he suggest, for example, that a submarine is less effective in southern waters than in northern waters? The whole concept of that approach really is quite ludicrous.

There is a major upgrade in both the navy and the air force. The right honourable gentleman mentioned the F111Cs and the F111Gs. Currently, some $46 million is being expended on new avionics and fighter support systems in the F111. When that is completed, Australia will have, unarguably, the most advanced fighter bomber capacity in our part of the world. It is not to be sneezed at. He forgot to mention that the FA18 is still probably the most advanced fighter aircraft in the world and most certainly in our region. In terms of air force capacity, Australia is well placed, and is far in advance of any comparable country in our region, in terms of air strike capacity.

The new frigates are not to be sneezed at. They do incorporate Australian adaptions to foreign design. If we look at what the Collins class submarines have done by using Australian designed pumps on their torpedo systems, it is clear that Australia has adapted a foreign design to make a far more effective fighting unit than the original foreign design provided. One only needs to read the newspapers to know that the new torpedo firing systems have dramatically expanded the torpedo firing capacity of the Collins class submarine.

Overall, it is a rather fallacious argument for the opposition to attack this government on the quantity of money being spent on defence. Nevertheless, I have to say to this House that, being very familiar with the Armoured Corps and having frequent contact with it, I am concerned that we are expending far too much money on two services and are neglecting the army. Enormous sums of money are going into the Collins submarine program and the frigate program. I cannot argue that that is not a desirable thing. At the same time, the RAAF is being equipped with the best and most up-to-date design systems in their fighter aircraft. However, the Leopard tank is now an old tank. It lacks a night firing capacity, and there are far superior armoured vehicles now on the market which would more than match the Leopard's capacity.

One only has to travel around the world to our near neighbours to find that the surplus Russian tanks, which are a fine fighting machine, are being sold at quite cheap prices right around the northern regions. One must wonder why some of our Asian neighbours feel the need to have rather large armoured brigades when they have no local defence threat to themselves. Maybe it is just a quest for power in the region or a need to be seen to be an independent, strong defence force nation. But it cannot be justified in terms of threat assessment anywhere in the Asian region.

To all who are concerned with defence in Australia, it must be worrying to realise that the Russians have an enormous surplus of both the T72 tank and the T80 tank. From memory, the T80 and the T72 are both fitted with the 155 millimetre cannon, which is heavy artillery. They are very large tanks indeed. If members get the chance to visit Puckapunyal, they will be pleased to know that the Australian Army has a T72 on the site of the armoured school in the museum of armour. I have had a look at the T72 and it is, indeed, a very vicious looking weapon.

Most modern tanks have a modular system of armour which enables different armour to be placed on the tank for different circumstances. The Leopard does not have that capacity. The new Abraham, a US tank, is a large, vicious looking beast of a thing. It has the capacity to have ceramic armour placed on the outside, which is a missile protecting armour that protects the tank from certain missile attacks.

That is a desirability for our Armoured Corps, and one that we should look at very seriously in upgrading our armoured system. I cannot agree with the right honourable member for New England when he suggests that the new LAV, which is a Canadian made and designed wheeled vehicle, is not suitable for Australian conditions. Indeed, I can say to the house that that is not the view of the Armoured Corps, which assessed a number of vehicles on the market and discovered the LAV. In fact, the LAV has been selected by the United States Marines as a most suitable light armoured personnel carrier; and that is its function.

It can be argued very strongly that the LAV, with its six-wheel drive system, has far more adaptability to northern conditions, as it can go through swamps and sand and is not limited—as many tracked vehicles in fact are, particularly very heavy tracked vehicles. I can say to the right honourable member and to the House that, from my instructions and from my understanding of the view of the Australian Armoured Corps, it is more than satisfied with the LAV as a new vehicle for northern purposes.

There are some things we should do fairly urgently for the Armoured Corps, and one of them is to install modern, updated airconditioning systems in the Leopard tanks. It cannot be argued that the Leopard should not be placed in our northern areas. If Australia is going to be attacked, the attack will unarguably come from the north. A proper decision was made to base the bulk of the land army in the north. Of course, you do not let infantry go without the armour to protect those troops. So the bulk of the Leopard tanks are now situated in the north.

I do not know if anyone in this House has been in a Leopard. They are fairly confining, on the inside. They are all steel, of course, and when the lid is down and you are in the turret, for example, there is not much air. They have a fan system which puts air through the tank, but can one imagine the conditions our soldiers now face when the tanks are in the north and they are in a combat position on a training exercise with lids down. They get bloody hot, and I am being kind when I say that. They get awfully hot. At the moment, our soldiers are up there exercising in vehicles which have no airconditioning. I have approached the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), and I feel very strongly that our soldiers in the north should, in fact, have decent airconditioning systems put into the Leopard tanks.

Along those lines, the army is currently evaluating its need for new armour, and there are several possibilities that may be taken up. The army may decide not to go for airconditioning if, down the track in a very short space of time, the Leopards are replaced by a newer, and much lighter, light armoured tank. I have been briefed on various possibilities for the Armoured Corps in that area. They are the experts; I am not. Sometimes, we in the House have a shopping list of things that, for a variety of reasons, we would like to see in the defence forces but, ultimately, the government must take the advice of the services, in terms of the equipment that they get within budgetary constraints.

At the outset, I totally reject the claims of the right honourable member that we have neglected the Australian defence forces in budgetary terms. I can only remind the House that, when I first went back into Puckapunyal in 1984—after having served there in national service and citizen military forces some years ago—I was shocked and horrified at the abysmal conditions we are asking our service personnel to live in. There were houses with sloping floors and doors that did not open or close. One thing I am proud to say is that this government, at least, has diverted a lot of money to ensure that service personnel now live in decent houses. In Puckapunyal, there are over 100 new brick veneer homes being built as decent housing for our personnel, who now live in far better circumstances than those I saw in 1984.

But even better than that is the fact that the individual single soldier, or the soldier on transfer for training purposes away from home base, now has accommodation in flats, which is far more appropriate than the dormitory situation that I first saw. That has all gone. There are now decent living conditions—something which is important for morale, especially if we are going to encourage into the defence forces the sort of people we need today of extremely high technical capability.

In brief, I reject outright the claims of the right honourable member for New England that we have neglected the forces. There are restraints on budgets and we recognise that. But it is sheer hypocrisy for members of the opposition to put that charge to this government when they called for a $400 million cut in the defence vote in Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is depressing that this defence white paper, this strategic document, has speakers in this House speaking about tactical issues. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) did touch on a couple of strategic issues when he talked about Australia's own native defence capacity, our capacity to build for ourselves. But I remind the right honourable member that it was the government of which he was a part that made the decision to destroy the Australian aircraft industry, which it did, when it opted to buy the F111 instead of joint venture in the TSR2. It might be worth pointing out that the F111 was originally a British design, designed by Barnes Wallis, and given to the Americans. The TSR2 exceeded its expectation on its maiden flight. The F111 has never met its design capacities, although it is, of course, a very good aircraft.

PARA.TAB: I would also point out to the right honourable member for New England that when I alone in this House was concerned about the submarine acquisition program what we had from the opposition, apart from the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Aldred), was a deafening silence.

I want to deal with the strategic issues. If this defence white paper, Defending Australia, is meant to be a serious statement of our defence strategy, then I am disturbed. I notice that even Greg Sheridan, one of the foremost propagandists of the Manifest Asian Destiny or MAD school, thinks that Defence has gone too far in its emphasis on Asia in this paper. If Sheridan with his lamentable Asian cringe thinks that, then it is something that must really be wrong.

It is clear that defence planners are desperate. On the one hand, they are desperate to fit in with the government's general Asian theme in foreign affairs, trade and immigration whilst, on the other hand, they are desperate to avoid giving offence to Asian nations in our region. The Department of Defence and the defence chiefs know at first hand the power of political correctness. Perhaps, given recent bruising experiences, they think that it is best to be seen to be playing the politically correct game whilst keeping secret the more touchy aspects of the policies.

Just as Senator Joseph McCarthy attacked the US military as a way of promoting his own career, so the politically correct of the day, the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Sue Walpole, and her ilk have attacked the military, particularly the navy for the supposedly systematic and terrible harassment of women. They are onto a good thing. First, they agitate for increased numbers and responsibility for women in the military, and then they say women are being treated terribly. They may find one or two cases, but they exaggerate to make it the general rule. All the while they can posture as outstanding human rights warriors.

Homosexual activists have also sought to dictate recruitment policies as a matter of personal status—not that they have any concern for the best interests of the military. Under pressure from the professional ethnic lobby there is also a push to recruit people on the basis of their ethnic background. Also, the republican push makes it necessary that the terrible British base of our services must be undermined. And so it goes on.

The political correct will not rest until they have insinuated their ideology into every institution in the country. They see the military as one of the last bastions of old Australia which they are determined to extirpate. They do not care about the cost to morale and efficiency. If morale is low, we will have great difficulty in attracting the best people to the services.

Military chiefs and career officers feel uncomfortable in engaging in public disputes and have generally capitulated before such attacks. But I am sure that the great bulk of the military would have cheered them if they had come out fighting across the board against this insidious and highly politicised interference. Unfortunately, they are unlikely to have succeeded in any event. They are no match for the polished and articulate McCarthyists and their media propagandists, even though they know the McCarthyist attacks are unjust and adversely affect morale.

Is it any wonder that they think a bit of public relations camouflage is in order. I can understand it. I feel sorry for the military. They have dedicated themselves to the service of our country knowing that in the grave possibility of war they may be called on to lay down their lives. This should be a profession honoured throughout the land. Instead, the military is attacked by professional do-gooders who bleed public funds for their purposes. These are the people who know nothing about what it takes to run a military machine and they have absolutely no empathy for the people who choose the military as a career.

I ask: how many of the politically correct would put their lives on the line for Australia? They would be among the first to head elsewhere if Australia faced war. The professional ethnics in particular, with their sentimental allegiances to foreign nations, would be among the first to scuttle to the airports for departure. Australia is just a funding base to them. It is not something worth fighting for when real dangers are involved.

Yet the influence of these people is such that the military bows before it. At the very least, the defence planners feel the need to fit in with the fashions to avoid new bruises—to give the government and the politically correct establishment what it thinks it wants to hear and to play its part in the Asian public relations effort.

I found it amusing that copies of this paper were delivered to military attaches from Asian nations before it was actually presented to the Senate by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). Perhaps we can be less critical of this paper if we view much of it as an exercise in public relations. Perhaps our defence planners do not really believe that Indonesia can be relied on to basically be the sheet anchor of our defence. Perhaps they are keeping their real policies secret. If these real policies were based on a commonsense strategic assessment, I would understand. Commonsense has been ruthlessly extinguished as a basis for policy in Australia and I doubt that there is more than a handful of the professional serving officers who really believe that this paper tells it like it is.

Let us consider some of its main points. There is a restatement of the belief that no country has the capacity to seize and hold major Australian territory and that no country has the desire to do so in the foreseeable future. In consequence, the main preparations should continue to be for potential low level conflict and continued coverage of the air-sea gap. There is a belief that Indonesia can and should be cultivated as a major and reliable ally, but I think it is foolish to build your entire policy on this belief. The next main point in the report is a supposed restatement of defence self-reliance, with defence of the continent a priority, but also increasing regional cooperation with China, India and Japan and an emphasis on participation in United Nations peacekeeping forces.

The next point is the relocation of land forces to Darwin. The 2nd Cavalry Regiment is already there and will be joined by the 1st Armoured Regiment, the 5th/7th Battalion and the remainder of the 1st Brigade. By the way, those deluded characters who have been trying to whip up a new `Brisbane Line' conspiracy in which the north will supposedly be militarily abandoned are not only wide of the mark, as this movement of personnel shows, but diverting attention from the real problems with our defence posture.

There has been an upgrading of air and naval forces, but ADF personnel numbers will be maintained at the present level for the next 15 years. Defence spending is to remain at its present level. There is to be the upgrading of the training of the reserves. The belief is stated that our security involves an integrated approach embracing defence, foreign policy, trade and immigration. There will be reliance on an early warning from intelligence to reveal any potentially hostile build-up of forces in the region—an intelligence which I might say was lamentably lacking in relation to events in Fiji.

A major strategic initiative is to push for closer defence relations with Asia, including China, India and Japan. This approach is taken as being complementary to the government's trade and foreign and immigration policies, deluded as they are.

Indonesia is presented as a key ally, yet there are deep instabilities beneath the surface in Indonesia. We have only to look at examples of the 1960s to see how quickly circumstances can change in that country. There is always the potential for an expansionist Islamic fundamentalism to become a force, particularly if the increasing economic prosperity of the new middle classes does not `trickle down' to the great bulk of the population. There is likely to be growing discontent under these circumstances and, as in Egypt and Algeria, Islamic fundamentalism could be an attractive option for those who miss out.

Many so-called educated economists have predicted a golden age of prosperity in the Asia-Pacific that will make military action redundant. The defence paper at least acknowledges that economic growth is not a guarantee of stability in the region and that prosperity means the opportunity to buy more and better weapons, which other nations will feel the need to match, resulting in a potential arms build-up. However, the paper does not follow through with the implications of this and prefers to cultivate a false sense of security, perhaps to avoid insulting our neighbours, and particularly the Indonesians.

Indonesia is seen as a possible strong ally, largely because of its fear of China, it seems, and Australia is an unthreatening neighbour with whom it can cooperate for its own security. But what if Indonesia is able to forge an alliance with China? These nations are far closer culturally. Where would that leave Australia? Indonesia may well grow tired of constant carping from Australia—even if it is not coming from government circles—about human rights abuses and the army's handling of internal security matters, particularly if the regime is seriously threatened internally. China certainly would not be so rude.

A good way of diverting attention from internal instability is to unite against a common external foe and one that can be presented, as our own new class has presented us, as a greedy and wealthy hogger of a vast landmass. Throw in our nasty racism, which even our own government accuses us of before international forums, and they have all the justification they need.

No natural affinity for us exists in either Japan or India. While they may want a cut of the action, they certainly would not come to our aid. While the USA may be sympathetic and sell us equipment which is not sold to Indonesia, it is an ally of Indonesia and it would be highly unlikely to intervene in a conflict between Indonesia and Australia.

From the point of view of Australia's security, the increased use of scarce military resources to bolster usually impotent United Nations peacekeeping ventures is also a waste of time. Will the United Nations assist us if we have problems? Even if it did, there is little a puny UN force could do against a determined attacker.

The UN may prove to be more of an enemy than a friend. As the politically correct within Australia continue to denounce us internationally, the cry may be taken up by the United Nations to sanction large-scale population movements from Third World nations. How would we respond to a large fleet of refugee boats from China or Bangladesh, approved by the United Nations, approaching our shores? How would we defend ourselves against that? What would happen if an opportunistic aggressor took advantage of the chaos caused by such a fleet and mounted an attack behind it? Not only could these boats be helped towards us by such an aggressor, but simultaneous refugee movements could be provoked from places such as Irian Jaya and East Timor to add to the chaos.

I hope Defence has considered such possibilities, because they are certainly credible scenarios—not in the short term perhaps, but in the long term with population pressures in the region likely to be enormous within the next 20 to 30 years. These are the sorts of things we have to prepare for.

As I have indicated, one of our biggest concerns is the `new class' elites at home which have actively weakened and divided our nation and undermined the military. If this sort of behaviour continues we will decline as a stable nation and our ability to defend ourselves will continue to be eroded. Meanwhile, our potential enemies, unaffected by such new class parasites, will grow stronger. At any rate, we have to rid ourselves of the delusion that we can rely on regional neighbours in any emergency. When it comes to the crunch, we will be on our own. It would be nice if the government had the guts to accept that and plan accordingly.

Of course we should aim for good relations with Indonesia and other Asian countries, but we should not rely upon them as a basic foundation of our defence. The government's so-called defence self-reliance leaves us heavily dependent on US-sourced equipment. Industrially, we are weak and our defence spending is poor. Our personnel problems in Defence will not be addressed. Add this to our cringing foreign affairs stance and our absurd immigration policy, and the powers that be may well make us `part of Asia' sooner than we think. Let us hope that our new masters are humanitarians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dodd Mr P.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment on the defence white paper is to refer to the ministerial statement made by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). It is important that we bear in mind Senator Ray's comments when discussing the white paper. He says:

PARA.TAB: Despite all the hopes and aspirations we share for reducing the chances of conflict since the end of the Cold War, military force is still an important element in international affairs, and will remain so.

This is a fact of life—regrettably—but a fact nevertheless. It is also a fact that, while we will do all we can to avoid the use of force ourselves, ultimately, armed force can only be resisted by armed force.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a timely reminder that the focus of any defence policy should be the maintenance of peace. That is very important. We have come to the end of the Cold War. One of the consequences of that is, unfortunately, a likely increase in regional conflict. Again, Senator Ray says:

The key judgement in this white paper is that fundamental changes in strategic affairs, both globally and within our region, will make Australia's strategic environment more demanding over the next fifteen years.

I think that is a very true statement. We did think the Cold War was over. I thought that until I was reading the Courier-Mail this week. There are still some Cold War warriors out there. I looked with astonishment at the headline in the Courier-Mail on Wednesday `West lashed over attempt to ban reds'. That was the headline that prompted me to looked to see who the reds were. I was quite interested to find that the reds were Boris Yeltsin and Russia. Apparently, for the Courier-Mail at least, the Cold War is still not over. It still refers to Boris Yeltsin and his government as the reds. I guess that is one for Stuart Littlemore.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the Cold War has changed the perception of threats to Australia. Up to the middle of the 1980s, Australians saw the threat as coming from the Soviet Union, according to the opinion polls. Indonesia was ranked second in those days but by the end of the 1980s and the end of the Cold War the Australian public came to regard Indonesia as the most likely threat to Australia's security. In 1993 a national survey revealed that some 57 per cent of Australian voters believed that Indonesia would pose a security threat to Australia within 10 to 15 years. That is the public perception, and perhaps the issue of East Timor has something to do with Australians thinking that there is some security threat from the Indonesian government.

Nevertheless, it is true, as suggested by my earlier quote from Senator Ray, that an end to the Cold War does change the strategic environment in our region. I am indebted to an article by Des Ball headed `The political-security dimension of Australia and the Asia-Pacific region' in the Indonesian Quarterly of July this year for some comments in which he highlights the nature of these changes. He points to the changes in South-East Asia and the restructuring of the defence forces from counter-insurgency capacities that obviously reflected the Cold War conflict to modern high technology forces. Des Ball sees that as perhaps highlighting a mini arms race in South-East Asia. He points to increased regional tension—although the article was written pre-APEC—and he also points to the offensive nature of the new weapon systems. He quotes `maritime attack aircraft, modern surface combatants, submarines equipped with anti-ship missiles' as examples of this heightened arms race in South-East Asia.

We have to look at what the Australian response will be, and that is partly contained in the white paper. With regard to Australia's response, Des Ball quite clearly comes down on the side of regional cooperation, as does the white paper, as the only course of action for Australia. In his article, Des Ball provides eight very significant imperatives for regional cooperation.

The first is that regional cooperation is necessary to counter centrifugal possibilities within the region. The second reason he gives concerns the various major advance weapon acquisition programs currently under way in the region. He says that it is critical that these acquisition programs not lead to a regional arms race. I think that is very important. In the third reason he highlights the character of new weapon systems being acquired, and the fourth reason in favour of regional cooperation is that it provides a combined counterweight to the intrusions of other powers into the region. He cites as the fifth reason that all countries in the region have a concern with the international law of the sea, which I do have not time to talk about now.

A sixth and very important reason he offers is that many of the current and prospective regional security developments can only be addressed on a cooperative basis. His seventh reason is that the increasing rapidity of change and the relatively novel nature of emerging security problems demand an unfettered flow of ideas and dialogue on policy initiatives and means of addressing common problems, a reason that I think is very important. His final reason is that, more positively, regional cooperation is necessary for the achievement of regional resilience.

Without going into further detail, I suggest it is obvious that those reasons have a lot of cogency, and that Australia has no alternative but to cooperate with the rest of South-East Asia. We have obviously done so in a trade sense with APEC, and we have no choice but to do that in relation to the military. We are all in the one boat, as it were, in South-East Asia. There is no alternative. When we are talking about Indonesia, however, we cannot ignore the issues of human rights. It would assist if the Indonesian government did consider some degree of self-determination for both East Timor and Irian Jaya, since it is certainly the case that Tasmania has more regional independence in Australia than Timor or Irian Jaya, very sadly, would have in Indonesia. If, for whatever reason, complete independence for East Timor is impossible, the Indonesian government—if it is serious about cooperation on a regional basis—should consider some further self-determination for East Timor.

Des Ball's article also points to many regional security concerns: piracy, pollution from oil spills, illegal fishing, and exploitation of our offshore resources. All these concerns relate to the region in which I live and which I represent. They all point to the importance of the defence of Northern Australia, which is increasingly becoming the focus of Australia's defence strategy—and rightly so. Obviously, it is the site of an increased defence presence in terms of capacity, bases and personnel. The area which I represent and other parts of northern Australia have very close links with South-East Asia through trade and other cultural contacts which will obviously diminish misunderstanding and will enhance cross-cultural contact—which, in itself, helps in the long run to diminish any possible military conflict in the future, simply through cultural cross-fertilisation.

The white paper highlights the Defence Force's increased operations in northern Australia, and the surveillance of maritime areas of northern Australia particularly. I was very disappointed with the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who chose to make the very cheap point about the fact that certain boat people—I do not think they were Indonesian—were found in the streets of Darwin and the police were rung. Everyone has heard this story, which is very funny. But no-one seriously suggests that there was a threat to Australia's security in that situation, so how can the defence forces be criticised? It was really a very cheap point, given the nature and difficulty of northern surveillance, to take this incident and somehow raise it in the House today with regard to the defence white paper. I am very disappointed in the right honourable member for New England for having done that.

The white paper makes the very important point that the ability to locate and monitor potentially hostile forces in our sea and air approaches and on our territories is essential to prevent or nullify threats to our interests. The northern coastline is significant in my electorate, and the Torres Strait is of great strategic importance. I pay tribute now to the contribution of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the defence of northern Australia.

The Scherger air base is a very important part of the potential northern defence of Australia. The white paper says that the chain of northern air bases will be completed later this decade and that we will work until the Scherger air force base on Cape York Peninsula is completed. I am advised that that project, which people may know is just outside of Weipa, is due for completion in 1999 and may be completed earlier. Already built in that base is a camp for 200 people; a kitchen to feed 400 people; a temporary power station, with a central power station to be completed early in 1995; and a workshop. This is all being done by local contractors and is providing jobs.

An air cargo hangar is being constructed and half of the runway is now complete. That has been done by both army and local contractors. I am advised that in 1995 a tender will be called for an ordnance loading area at an estimated cost of $7 million to $10 million. There will also be a tender for the placement of hard rock. Scherger air base is a very significant example of cooperation. I understand there has just been an environmental audit which has again given the progress of work a tick. It is an example of cooperation with the local community, with involvement of local contractors. The Aboriginal people from Napranum community successfully completed the contract for the fencing of the Scherger air base and, of course, other contractors have benefited.

In the long run, Scherger will not be a fully operational base. But, as I pointed out earlier, there is a camp for 200 people and 400 people can be fed. So obviously, in any future operation, it will become a vital part of Australia's defence of the north.

I am pleased to have this base in my electorate. Not only does it provide jobs in the short term but also it is an example—as is the presence of the 51st battalion in Cairns and HMAS Cairns naval base—of the fact that Australia is being well defended and that the emphasis on defence of the north is important. The thrust of the white paper is obviously on the right track. The matters that I referred to earlier suggest that Australia has no choice but to seek defence cooperation with other parts of Asia, and I think that is highlighted in the white paper. I commend the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and I commend all those who produced the white paper for an excellent blueprint for Australia's defence into the next century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

PARA.TAB: I think it goes further than that in the context of our present expanding and excellent—that is not too strong a word to use—relationship at the military level with Indonesia. The events leading up to the first parliamentary elections in Cambodia significantly raised Australia's profile—not only in the wider United Nations family context but within our region—as a nation which is concerned about security and the wellbeing of the people of South-East Asia.

In concluding, I will make some remarks on a matter which I brought to the attention of this House on no fewer than two occasions in the past. This matter raises very serious questions about accountability and the culture of the Department of Defence. It concerns the case of Sylvia Margaret Faulkner, which I have raised before in this place.

In the past few days, I have received more documents from the Attorney-General's Department, under my FOI request, which appear to confirm my worst suspicions about the conduct of the Commonwealth's legal defence against Mrs Faulkner's compensation claim in which the defence department was the client. The crucial document is a minute dated 6 February 1987 from Mr Peter Swinton, a senior official in the Attorney-General's Department's legal services section, to Mr Robert Muecke, the head of the litigation division of the Attorney-General's Department. This was just two months before the court hearing of Mrs Faulkner's claim relating to an alleged breach of contract by the defence department over the purchase of her invention, the trisal clip.

The minute outlines discussions between Mrs Swinton and the QC advising the Commonwealth, Mr Jack Hiatt. What it suggests very strongly is that the Commonwealth, through its legal officers and the defence department, deliberately set out to influence the evidence presented at the trial by the key witness for the defence, former Brigadier Charles Flint. This document states:

SPEECH.PARA: It was strongly suggested—
that is, by Mr Hiatt—

that when any approach is next made to the Department of Defence, the question of Mr Flint's involvement be raised and finalised. In other words, it should be put to the department that Flint has run the gamut of departmental proceedings and ought not to have his pension subject to alteration as a result of anything which might take place in the course of the hearing. If the client—
that is, Defence—
agrees that that is the departmental position, then it should be requested to confirm that and Flint should be informed.
It goes on to make it clear how important Flint's evidence is:

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I note that almost the entire press gallery, which has been preoccupied during the last month in a frenzied pursuit of the Liberal Party, has patently failed to report these extraordinary developments in this issue of major public interest. No-one should have to wait 20 years to have a case settled through the judicial system of the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to come into this debate, but then I listened to the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd), a member representing the forefront of our defence system, the most northerly part of Australia, and found his remarks quite extraordinary. His remarks were extremely critical of any sort of action by the government to defend Australia. He pooh-poohed and ridiculed statements made in the northern media that were critical of our defence capacity and our ability to protect our coastline when some people—I think they were Indonesians—landed in Far North Queensland. He apparently thought this was quite all right and he made remarks in newspapers and in the northern media along those lines—most extraordinary statements and most extraordinary behaviour. But, of course, he is in the mainstream of Labor thinking.

PARA.TAB: I recently read a book on the life of John Curtin. A lot of people seem to have the impression that he was a very good person. I became so angered when reading about Mr Curtin that I threw the book away, which is something I rarely do. This person before the Second World War had continuously fought against every single allocation of moneys for armaments. The net result of that was that we went into the war with virtually nothing at all to fight with and to defend our own shores with. In fact, he as Prime Minister had allowed almost every one of our troops to fight in Africa instead of leaving them at home to protect against the very imminent danger of invasion.

There were two reasons why the international socialists and their successors continuously have this attitude. They have a belief that the only people who cause wars are the capitalist class; therefore, all wars are bad by definition and we should not fight in them because we are serving the interests of the capitalist class. Often it seems to be forgotten that the original attack on Poland, which precipitated the war, was undertaken from the south by Germany and from the north by the socialist empire of Russia. Russia—the great hero of the Labor movement in Australian during that period of time—was the invader and part of the precipitating factor for the Second World War.

We went into war with virtually no armaments whatsoever. The only aeroplanes we had were the Wirraways. Not one single Wirraway, if my memory serves me correctly, brought down a single Japanese plane and every single one that went up was shot down out of the skies. We had virtually no tanks or heavy artillery whatsoever, nor did we have conscription. To our eternal shame, we had no conscription even during the war. There was no conscription for fighting overseas thanks to the leadership given by the socialists. There was a continuous coal strike throughout the entire Second World War which imposed electricity rationing throughout Australia. This was the effort made by the people. Not one single striker or person who put on overtime bans was brought to heel by the then government.

Similarly, still with the socialists in the saddle, we were sent into the Korean War carrying 303 rifles against the Chinese, who were carrying automatic weapons. At the present moment there are some great ideas and this white paper has some very excellent ideas. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) spoke very sensibly about the white paper. But there is no implementation of the ideas on the ground whatsoever. There has been a site cleared at Longreach for the Jindalee over-the-horizon radar and that is all that has happened. We have heard all sorts of noises being made, but all we have is a cleared piece of ground. At the proposed air force base near Weipa, again there has been nothing but noise. Nothing substantive has happened at all.

Things that are desperately and importantly needed, such as Jindalee and some sort of naval capability to back up Jindalee, simply do not exist and, quite frankly, on present monetary allocations, they most certainly will not exist in the future. I think there are 32 Blackhawk aircraft in Australia—they represent out capability to rapidly deploy our armed force—and five of them are operational. We are paying pilots of the Blackhawks an enormous amount of money—and quite rightly so; they are very experienced and highly qualified men—but they do not fly. They get virtually no flying time at all. This was quite foreseeable since we have only five operational aircraft.

People say there is no danger and immediate threat to Australia. In the United Kingdom, Winston Churchill was laughed at in parliament for a protracted period of time because he said there were grave dangers. Right up to 1938 he was still serving on the backbench and being laughed at by the collective wisdom of the parliament and the media in England. Maybe that mistake led the world into the Second World War. If people like him had been listened to sooner, maybe there would not have been a war.

But the lesson for Australia is the lesson of Israel, where 3 1/2 million people have been able to hold off sustained attacks by some 200 million Arabs. The lesson for Australia is the lesson of Sweden. Sweden was left alone in the Second World War because every single Swede had a rifle and was military trained. If you did not have to take on an army of over one million people—that is the number that Sweden effectively could quickly put on the ground—why do it? It was put in the too-hard basket. Because it was militarily strong, Sweden was the one country in Europe that came out of the war.

We need some serious defence of our coastline, not only to guard against external threats to our security but also because of drug running, illegal immigration and health worries—foot and mouth disease, which is endemic in Indonesia, could be brought into our country. Then there is the requirement for constant patrolling by our military of the seas surrounding Australia—no-man's land, if you like—and the constant agitation by the Torres Strait Islanders that they are not being protected at all. People from Indonesia continuously come through the Torres Strait and are not assailed. In fact, we do not have the ability to assail anyone coming in because, if a Coastwatch aircraft does sight a vessel—be it from New Guinea, Indonesia, New Britain, the Philippines or Taiwan—the nearest vessel that can react, pick up and apprehend these vessels is back at Cairns. I do not think the Taiwanese or the Indonesian vessels will stand around waiting for 24 hours for the cavalry to arrive while there is an aircraft circling overhead. I very much doubt whether that is going to occur; it does not happen. That is why the coastal defence systems are entirely inadequate.

Unfortunately, the Coastwatch service is laughed at in Far North Queensland. The member for Leichhardt does not know that because he does not come from there. Very soon he will be leaving; he is the same as the bloke I knocked off in the last election.
Mr Dodd interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—The honourable member for Leichhardt should not interject and the honourable member for Kennedy should not provoke him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note the member's interjection that he will be around in North Queensland a lot longer than my family and I. Let that go on the record.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If he keeps pursuing it, I will quote—

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Leichhardt.

—One of the leading ALP supporters in Cairns described him as one of the most stupid people he had ever had anything to do with in politics in Australia. You can set your watch by the Coastwatch people because they go at a predictable time on a predictable day of the week. I hope that has stopped, but a few months ago I was told by a group of fishermen in no uncertain terms that you could set your watch by the Coastwatch because they come at a predictable time on a particular day of the week. When I checked up on this two years ago—I did not check up on this occasion—that most certainly was the case and it appears that nothing has been done about it in the intervening time.

PARA.TAB: For those who believe in an egalitarian society where all people are equal, national service pushes the rich and the poor together, the well-educated and the uneducated together, black, white and yellow people together. It creates a great cohesive force. I am not in any way advocating along the lines of national service. I did military training for many years and I can see absolutely no justification for having military training for anything over two or three months. It is hard to go past the Swedish and the Israeli model. It would achieve so many other objectives, such as an egalitarian society, which we most certainly do not enjoy in Australia today. It would also give us the potential to defend ourselves, having such a huge continent with such a tiny population.

The other problem which is so relevant to defence is that one-third of Australia's entire water resources are locked up in North Queensland. We have a tiny population of 500,000 occupying that huge land mass which has enough soil and water to support a population of, I suppose, about 10 or 15 million without any difficulty whatsoever, yet there is no-one living there.

Professor Richard Blandy, most certainly no supporter of our side of politics, wrote a very interesting article on population. He pointed out that the Australian population in 100 years from today will be about five million. Officially, we are a vanishing race. I have yet to hear anyone in this place assail what must be the most serious problem for a race of people, that they will simply cease to exist. In the Year of the Family, nothing has been done to help young families to afford to have children in Australia, to make it a little easier for them.

The other element which I think needs canvassing today is human rights policy. I do not think the government is doing it consciously, but it is constantly and continually carping and lecturing to the Asian nations about human rights and all of those issues. There was a very great American president, Theodore Roosevelt, who said, `Walk quietly and carry a big stick.' The imbeciles that run this country are doing just the opposite. They are walking loudly and carrying no stick at all. I suspect some of these Asian nations have a memory for these sorts of things and they carry a big stick. They have not been hesitant, if you look at history, in using the big stick in the past. I do not think they will hesitate to use it in the future.
We need Jindalee. We need it now. We need some defensive boats, whether they be patrol boats or something bigger in the Torres Strait. We need a company of soldiers based in the Torres Strait.

I do not necessarily talk exclusively about some threat to our security. I reiterate: there is a problem with drugs, disease and our fisheries. PARA.TAB: The law of the land that we inherited from Great Britain was that a country owned the land within cannon shot. That was fairly logical when you think about it. Our cannons today are far bigger and have a far greater range. To assert our control, we really need to put some people up there and not leave the people of Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait feeling abandoned. That most certainly is the feeling they have at the present moment. If there are two or three Taiwanese vessels and only one little coastguard boat there, they feel completely unprotected. That is not the way any Australian should feel.

Australia not only needs that sort of forward capacity and capability, particularly in the missile area, but also needs to be able to field the sort of army that Sweden or Israel can field at very short notice. As an instructor in the militia for many years of my life, I can say that you do not need very long to train a person to protect his country.
