TALKER.NAME: Mr BEVIS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thank the House for its courtesy in allowing me to enter the debate again. The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) is quite priceless. We have just heard a range of issues dragged out of the 1950s manifesto that took us through the international socialists and the reds under the bed right through to conscription. It was the full ambit and it will make entertaining reading in Hansard for a lot of people, I am sure. It does not give much assistance, though, to the debate on the nation's defence, which is the issue that I want to turn to.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I sat in the House and listened to the response by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) to the white paper. As a person who had previously been a shadow minister for defence, I had thought that there might be some fairly considered and useful contribution from the opposition in an area which has, by and large, been the subject of bipartisan support, certainly on key questions. Sadly, that was not to be the case. The Leader of the Opposition commenced his speech by referring to the fact that he thought the white paper was several years too late. I am not quite sure whether the Leader of the Opposition had in mind exactly what a white paper is, what it does and what it is intended to construct for the future.

White papers are not the sort of thing that governments produce on an annual basis. The previous white paper on defence was in 1987. If you look at comparable documents in other countries, you will find that they are produced normally on the basis of seven- to 10-year time frames. This one was no different. My concern about the Leader of the Opposition's understanding of the process was made worse when he complained that the white paper restated the views that were in the 1993 strategic review. Of course they do. The strategic review is designed to provide a statement of our assessment of where we see the nation and our defence posture in our region.

The strategic review was set out last year accurately and properly—and I think it was well received by the Australian community and the defence community—to identify precisely that. Here we are about a year later taking that assessment, building on it and producing a white paper that puts out in some greater detail the way in which we as a nation will address that strategic circumstance over the five to 10 years ahead of us. But the Leader of the Opposition seemed to think there was something wrong, something deficient, with this white paper because it restated what was in the 1993 strategic review. I suspect the Leader of the Opposition has failed to understand the actual basis upon which these documents are constructed.

Let me turn to a couple of specific areas in his contribution. He alleged that there had been a reduction in defence capability. In support of that allegation, he said we had lost two of our six infantry battalions. I assume he is referring to the 1991 decision to replace two regular battalions with the introduction of the ready reserve battalions that occurred in 6th Brigade. I happen to know a little about 6th Brigade because not only is it within my electorate but also for the greater part of this year I have had portfolio responsibility for the ready reserve along with the general reserve. I take and have taken a very keen interest in the ready reserve since its announcement in 1991.

We previously had two regular battalions in 6th Brigade. There is nobody in 6th Brigade who will seriously argue that the capability now resident in 6th Brigade is anything other than substantially greater than the 6th Brigade that was in existence in 1991 before we made the changes. The fact of life is: those regular battalions within 6th Brigade—and there was then a general reserve battalion to make up the complement—were understaffed and had inadequate equipment levels. This government's approach has ensured that 6th Brigade is now staffed at much higher levels, has much more equipment and is now being motorised for mobility purposes. The 6th Brigade in 1994 is a far more capable brigade.

To suggest that that change has reduced capability—that is what was said by the Leader of the Opposition; it followed in his very next sentence where, to support his allegation of a cut in capability, he referred to this change—is patently wrong. The 6th Brigade is a far more potent force today than it was in 1991. But he compounded that felony when he went on to talk about surface combatants. He seemed to think that numbers and capability are interchangeable. The Leader of the Opposition supported his view about a reduction in defence capability by claiming that there has been a reduction in surface combatants and fewer submarines.

I find it astounding that, at a time when the government is committed to a major program of re-equipment with the Anzac frigates—a program which, I understand, has enjoyed bipartisan support; a project which has been pretty widely acclaimed in the parliament, industry and defence circles—the Leader of the Opposition should claim that we are reducing our capability on surface combatants. But, worse, he throws submarines into the argument. To suggest that our submarine capability is less when we are already trialling the first of the Collins class submarines that have been built in South Australia is just arrant nonsense. We are now in the process of upgrading our submarine fleet, to which we are committed under this white paper. The old Oberon submarines, with 1960s technology, we are replacing with absolute state-of-the-art technology to produce the most potent conventional powered submarines in the world. But the Leader of the Opposition does not seem to understand this. Just yesterday he said that we are reducing our capability in submarines. That is not the case.

The Leader of the Opposition does not understand what is happening in defence. If ever we needed a clearer example of that, he made it patently obvious when he started talking about the strengths within various battalions. He identified a number of battalions where he referred to what he called `nominal strength' and `actual strength'. He ran through a series of figures to say that a number of battalions are, by implication of his words, under strength. For the most part, the battalions he was talking about and the figures he was using were the difference between the authorised establishment and the posted strength. Sure, there is a difference between those two. Anyone who is involved in defence knows there is a difference between the authorised establishment and the posted strength of a battalion. The posted strength is invariably lesser—it is a smaller number.

Looking at the speech of the Leader of the Opposition, you will see that the posted strength in most of those battalions is about 30 or so people fewer than the higher figure—and that is usually as it is. There is nothing untoward about that; there is nothing new about that. But the Leader of the Opposition either does not understand the difference between an authorised establishment and a posted strength or was seeking to deceive and mislead. It is one or the other: he either does not understand it or he wanted to mislead people. I am not quite sure which it was since with the last of those battalions he mentioned he got it horribly wrong. He referred to the 5th/7th Battalion and said that that battalion has a `nominal operating strength' of 740 people. He went on to say that it actually has 480. That is a huge difference. When he said that, I thought `This could not be right'. So I have gone back to have a look to see what the situation is.

This `nominal operating strength' of 740 is not simply the authorised establishment for that battalion; it is the war establishment. If we were in the middle of a war, that is the level to which we would have that battalion manned. But yesterday the Leader of the Opposition stood here and rattled it off in a list of battalion strength numbers, claiming it to be a `nominal operating strength' and trying to claim that there is some deficiency in our capability. He does not know what he is talking about when it comes to defence. That is his best defence in answer to my comments today. He does not know what he is talking about. If he does know what he is talking about, then he came in here and quite improperly sought to convey an impression which he knew to be untrue. So he has a choice: he can claim incompetence or deception—one or the other—but there is no other answer available to him.

The opposition and other spokespeople at different times in this debate, both here and in the other chamber, have referred to the resourcing question. The resourcing question is a vitally important consideration in any portfolio allocation. It is particularly so in defence where there are, of necessity, very high costs. A lot tends to be made in these debates about the percentage of GDP, gross domestic product, allocated to particular portfolios. GDP or percentages of GDP are useful instruments for getting a gauge on international comparisons and getting a gauge over time on where you are at. But that is about all they are good for. Percentage of GDP does not buy anything. The percentage of GDP does not equate to any piece of equipment or any number of people. What buys equipment and people is money. Percentage of GDP quoted in isolation is a meaningless term that can be used and misused to substantiate whatever case you wish to pursue. All members in this place know that to be so.

Yesterday the Leader of the Opposition fell into that trap as well and decided to home in on the percentage of GDP as if it were the holy grail of the debate about defence. It is important, but it is not the sole test. That is why the white paper quite clearly sets out not simply a statement about GDP but a statement about actual dollars. In paragraph 14.5 of the white paper, the government says:

SPEECH.PARA: Some modest real growth in defence spending will however be needed later this decade and in the following decade.

That is a clear statement that there needs to be real growth in defence spending. That is the important part of the process. Do not worry about the percentage of GDP. Our friends in New Zealand went through a decade where their GDP did not grow at all; they had zero growth. At the same time, the Australian economy grew by 25 per cent. If you were to take two per cent of GDP in New Zealand against two per cent of GDP in Australia over the same time, you would get a very different answer in real growth terms.

PARA.TAB: One of the facts of life is that a percentage of GDP will not buy you a single soldier, a single tank, a single battleship or anything else; but money will. The government has made its intentions clear in the white paper. It has referred in that paper, quite properly, to maintaining defence spending at approximately two per cent of GDP. Of course it says `at approximately two per cent of GDP' because GDP fluctuates, but the important thing is the statement says there will be an increase in real terms.

It would not be too bad listening to the opposition talking about budgetary matters if it were actually going to do something to enhance the budget for defence itself. But it is not. This week we have had confirmed the opposition's view that the government should cut its spending of total outlays by $11.7 billion—that is, $11,700 million we should stop spending that we are spending today. That is not a little pocket of money; that is a major slice of the government budget which the coalition parties say we should stop spending. At the same time as telling us that we should cut $11.7 billion out of this budget—and that is not over time but in one hit, this year—those opposite hop up here and tell us that we should spend more on defence. When there is a debate on health, they tell us that we should spend more on health. When there is a debate on legal aid, they tell us that we should spend more on legal aid. You cannot have it both ways. Your hypocrisy on that stands out.

If we were to try today to get a detailed policy statement from the opposition about defence, we would not be able to. If we go back to the last election to get the last detailed policy statement of the opposition, we find that the opposition undertook to cut $200 million out of the defence budget. That is the opposition's policy that was taken to the last election. Those opposite wanted to cut $200 million out of defence and they have the hide, the hypocrisy and the cant to stand up in the parliament and try to attack the government, which has been about maintaining the defence effort in this nation.

That is exactly what we have done. Real growth in the defence effort of this nation has been maintained in real terms, except for the last year when there was a slight reduction. We have committed ourselves to real growth, and the opposition stands here and seeks to attack that when it stands on a platform of reduced government outlays. That policy will not stand up to scrutiny either in this place or by the public. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that the government issue another white paper on defence at this stage. As my colleague the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) indicated, the last defence white paper was issued in 1987. Quite dramatic changes, both global and regional, have taken place in relation to questions of defence technology, attitudes towards defence, priorities and relationships. As the member for Brisbane indicated, the purpose of a white paper is to indicate the general framework within which government policies are determined. The current defence white paper is attempting to look ahead over a period of something like 15 years.

PARA.TAB: One of the unfortunate realities at the present time is the fact that national governments do have a responsibility to ensure that they provide adequate defences—and I emphasise the word `adequate'—to ensure that their citizens are provided with a reasonable level of protection. Let me emphasise that I am one of those people who adopt a minimalist approach to the question of defence. I am not one of those sabre rattlers who suggest that a country the size of Australia, with only 17 million or 18 million people, would ever have the capacity—and should ever seek to have the capacity—to defend itself against the onslaught of major world powers. That would be absurd in the extreme and impossible absolutely.

We had a situation recently—and I am not attempting to denigrate Australia's defence effort—where a boatload of Asians landed on a beach near Darwin. No-one knew they were there until they were walking up the beach towards Darwin looking for the local police. We have an enormous coastline. Providing adequate surveillance of that coastline in itself is an enormous task. I am not one of those people who believe that Australia can or should seek to provide absolute defences. That is simply not possible and is recognised in the white paper.

The white paper provides a recognition of the fact that Australia, unlike the approach that we have taken so frequently in the past, must now look more closely to questions of regional arrangements, regional relationships, the changes that have taken place in our immediate Asian region—and in the Pacific region generally. Enormous and accelerating growth has taken place in many countries which are our near neighbours in the Asian sphere.

We have come a long way from the days when Australia looked to be in a position of dependence and subservience to Britain and dependence on the royal navy. The Second World War had the effect of changing our view to a closer relationship with the United States. We spoke for many years about the importance of what was referred to as the US alliance. ANZUS itself developed from those times and types of circumstances.

More recently, Australia has quite correctly concentrated its defence consideration on the types of undertakings which the United Nations has been involved in with its peacekeeping operations. We have also looked at and emphasised the importance of Australia concentrating its attention on its immediate region and building up, establishing and strengthening the types of relationships Australia has with the countries of Asia and the Pacific rim.

That is the way Australia needs to look in the future in developing its general approach towards defence strategy. It is no longer a simple question of Australia adopting a policy of either forward defences or fortress Australia. There is a recognition, particularly on the part of the present government, that Australia's defence requirements now and into the future will continue to be increasingly dependent upon a much more sophisticated, integrated, policy coordinated approach than that. One of the unfortunate realities is that governments have to give attention to and apply enormous volumes of national resources which could well be, and would preferably be, applied to improving the material comfort and security of its citizens rather than in simply securing its borders.

The whole basis of war is to be found in human qualities and group qualities which still persist: greed, belligerence, face saving, arrogance, national and international thuggery, and questions of national prestige and government prestige. Traditionally, the wars of the past were very closely related to questions of territorial ambitions, sources of raw materials and access to markets. The imperialist reality of world tensions and world conflict has been referred to—and, to a very large extent, it is still with us—but, fortunately, countries have now developed much more sophisticated ways to approach and pursue their economic objectives.

Now countries do more closely integrate, and seek to integrate and coordinate, their economies with other countries throughout the world. One of the greatest safeguards of peace is that countries now increasingly depend upon a coordinated and good relationship, an integrated relationship, with other countries. In those ways, and through those means, countries are now better able to secure and to advance the interests of their citizens.

World War I was to be a war to end all wars. World War II was a war against fascism. The capacity of the world now to unleash massive destruction means that those world wars of the past could never recur. If they were to recur, it would be the end of the world as we know it; it would be the end of human civilisation. But we do have continuing skirmishes.

Countries of the Third World, in particular, are seeking to secure their own defences. Unfortunately, too often they are seeking to increase and improve their capacity to wage local wars against their neighbours. In order to either wage wars or defend themselves, they need defence equipment and the facilities which are necessary for them to pursue those objectives.

In today's world, the US military industrial complex—particularly following the collapse of the Soviet Union and the collapse generally of eastern Europe—is the big player in what some people have chosen to refer to as the new world order. It is a concept which I have rejected ever since I first heard it.

The most recent figures to which I have access show that in 1992 the Third World—the most underdeveloped countries of the world—spent $A35,000 million on arms. The United States supplied 60 per cent of those arms. As a result of the problems in Russia, its share of supplying arms, defence facilities, equipment and supplies to the Third World is now down to six per cent. It is not as a result of any change in Russian attitude but as a result of a significant reduction in the Russian capacity to be involved.

In the aftermath of the collapse of the Soviet Union, the communist bloc and the global Cold War, as we understood it, we are now starting to see a revival of star wars nonsense. That program was going to absorb massive volumes of US productive capacity. In order to support and justify the allocation of funds and resources away from more elevated forms of human security and welfare, it is always necessary to find a threat. The Soviet Union was a threat that has disappeared overnight. Now there is a resurgence, a revival, a rediscovery, of the Chinese threat. We will hear more about it in the future.

I hope we do not have a revival of those maps that we all knew so well in the past. I refer to the maps that were drawn on a grid which made it look as though China dominated the whole of the Eurasian land mass. They had those giant red arrows coming down through Asia. They were the things that we needed to defend ourselves from.

We will also recall the domino theory—the belief that, if any one country in Asia fell to communism, then the others would follow like dominos. That proved not to be so. One of the most distressing developments of that attitude, that acceptance, that approach, was the disaster of Vietnam. On occasions like this, we should recall some of the facts of that brutal and brutalising experience. It was one of the worst experiences in the history of mankind.

The US lost over 47,000 troops in combat in Vietnam. Over 47,000 troops—largely young Americans—died in Vietnam. In excess of 10,000 who were not combat troops were also killed in Vietnam. American troops who were wounded in Vietnam exceeded 300,000, and we know the way in which those people were physically and mentally devastated by that experience. The average age of those combat personnel from the United States in Vietnam was 19 years—kids. The average age of American combat personnel in World War II was 26. We are bringing the age down; we are getting kids.

The war cost the United States $150,000 million in direct expenses. It brought about a withdrawal of the United States to within its own boundaries. It turned the United States from a creditor nation to a debtor nation. It brought about a significant contraction of the productive capacity of the United States. That, as much as any other reason, was the chief cause for the United States withdrawal. The indirect costs to the United States from Vietnam would probably equal the direct costs. That would make a total of $US300,000 million. The population of Vietnam is about 65 million. If they were concerned about the possibility that communism would prove to be attractive to those Vietnamese people, they could have taken those funds and given every man, woman and child in Vietnam almost $US5,000. That would represent in excess of 10 years of per capita income for all of the people in Vietnam.

The total tonnage of bombs dropped on Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia during that period was eight million. That was four times the total tonnage of bombs that were dropped by every combatant in the Second World War. That amount of tonnage—four times the amount dropped in the Second World War—was dropped on three little Asian countries. Some 1.5 million Vietnamese died after the US had decided in 1961 that it would save Vietnam from itself.
On 29 April 1965, former Prime Minister Menzies stood in this parliament and said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government is now in receipt of a request from the Government of Vietnam for further military assistance.

History has confirmed that no such request existed. But, as a result, we finished up with 500 young Australians dead and thousands maimed. They were conscripted by lottery. Their lives were devastated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that we resume this debate after having spent a while talking about the defence white paper. The other dimension to defence is the extent to which we in this region, of which Australia is part, are able to develop new relations—

TAB.EMPHASIS: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important that we understand that in our region there are opportunities for people to talk together in order to work out their difficulties. Within APEC, there is a forum whereby for the first time many countries of the region are meeting in an entirely different context. Those of us who were involved in the early days of the ASEAN formation wonder just where that group might eventuate. It comprised countries with many similarities, yet with probably as many differences as they had similarities. It has been remarkable that the ASEAN group has grown, flourished and produced the results that it has.

PARA.TAB: At the APEC conference, to which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) referred in his statement, Mr Suharto, the President of Indonesia, one of the leading members of the ASEAN group, was chair. It was from him that much of the inspiration of the results of Bogor was derived. All of us should pay tribute to President Suharto for the way in which he not only chaired the conference but also has been able to bring together countries, particularly Malaysia whose Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, seemed for a time so strongly opposed to the concept of APEC.

Nonetheless, in looking at the whole concept, several comments need to be made. The first is that, while all of us welcome and compliment the Prime Minister and the Australian government on their role, it needs to be recognised that the APEC conference has not been seen as such a great achievement in other member countries. Indeed, there has been concern in a number of the countries of APEC that Australia, the United States in particular and to a lesser degree Japan have taken over the running of APEC. While it is true that cannot be said as far as President Suharto's involvement at Bogor is concerned, I think it needs to be mentioned that only last week in the Bangkok Post, an English language newspaper distributed in Bangkok in Thailand, there was quite a significant article which suggested that some elements of the Thai establishment believed that the whole of the APEC concept has run off the rails.

I do not know that we could accept that. But I think it needs to be noted that, in a grouping of so many countries, inevitably there will be different emphases and different concerns. We need to make sure that, as this forum develops and continues, Australia will need not only to continue to make its input and try to direct the conference in areas where we believe there is a benefit to Australia but also to understand and listen to the points of other countries who may well have different emphases. It is a worry that this article suggested that some people in Thailand have reservations about APEC and the direction in which it is heading.

The second concern I have is that, while I acknowledge again the benefit of APEC to Australia, in reading the prime ministerial statement I felt that there is perhaps too much of an emphasis on the economic achievements rather than on the two areas that I think are particularly important. The first is that it is important to have the dialogue. It is a happy coincidence that this debate follows the debate on the white paper relating to Australia's defence attitudes.

If we are to try to overcome some of the problems of this global village which telecommunications is rapidly thrusting on us, it is going to be essential that there be not only forums in which to talk to each other but also an understanding of the person to whom we are talking. There is nothing quite like face-to-face dialogue in international discussions. Mr Speaker, I know that you and everyone who has represented Australia or the parliament abroad understands the advantage of that personal contact.

APEC brings together leaders of countries in much the same way as the South Pacific Forum has brought together the countries of the South Pacific. The leaders conference of ASEAN has brought together the leader countries of ASEAN. Those continued personal interfaces are not only an insurance against the need for future defence effort but also a way to overcome at a one to one level bilateral difficulties that might emerge. It is true that no multinational forum is going to replace those bilateral contacts. Bilateral contacts between nations are always going to be the basis of individual relationships. It is most important for Australia that we maintain our bilateral relations with all the countries of the area.

In that respect, I differ totally from my former colleague Malcolm Fraser. I read the other day that he is suggesting that the ANZUS agreement should now be set aside. To my mind that is absolutely ridiculous. I am disappointed that Malcolm Fraser does not understand that an agreement like ANZUS may not necessarily remain as it was when first negotiated by Sir Percy Spender but it should evolve. The relationship that we now have—albeit without New Zealand, which I think is regrettable—allows a considerable interchange between our countries which would not exist if we set the ANZUS agreement aside.

ANZUS is not just a defence relationship, it is a special bilateral dialogue between our nations. To my mind, the APEC conference should not replace any of these bilateral or multilateral associations. For example, we have the five-power defence arrangement which involves New Zealand, Australia, the United Kingdom, Malaysia and Singapore. I believe that that arrangement also needs to be maintained. APEC provides one to one dialogue. It should not replace other existing arrangements but should give us a better chance of maintaining, establishing and expanding the particular significance of the Asia-Pacific region.

In that respect, I think it has been quite fascinating to see the attitude of the Europeans. They are apprehensive that there may be a group growing in the Asia-Pacific area which could in some way combat the European Community. I think the Europeans could learn from APEC. In Europe they have set up barriers against outward involvement. It is that aspect of the European Community that has worried so many of us. Instead of trying to break down trade barriers not only with each other but also with the outside world, the Europeans have built up a fortress which makes it difficult for countries excluded from the union to deal with them.

That has created problems for Australia on the agricultural front. The common agricultural policy has regrettably been a major problem for this nation and its agricultural exports. To a degree the export enhancement program in the United States is a product of those tariff walls. APEC is not that sort of a body. The Europeans could learn from APEC in that sense.

It is also true that there are aspects of APEC about which we need to be concerned. Every Prime Minister, that I can recall, has always found it particularly heady wine once he moves into the uncertain seas of international politics. I think that Prime Minister Keating should keep that in mind.

There are areas within APEC that need emphasis. I have mentioned the concerns of some of the people in Thailand. One real omission that I have noted in the agreement is that there is no reference to social relations or health. One of the major worries in the world around us is the extent to which AIDS is spreading. It is important that a forum like APEC uses mutual contact in order to address particular social and health problems.

I notice that there does not seem to be any reference to health at all, within the areas that have been identified as important, in the whole of the Prime Minister's APEC statement. He identifies the areas of education and training and that is welcome. In that sense we could look at training nurses and health professionals. I am delighted to see that science and technology, small and medium enterprises, economic infrastructure—including energy, transportation, telecommunications and tourism—and sustainable development are all included in the statement. But it is important that it is not just an economic forum. I would suggest that we need to include in future deliberations issues related to social problems, health and matters that affect people.

I was pleased to see that there is going to be a voluntary consultative dispute mediation service. It is not going to replace but supplement that of the World Trade Organisation. A great deal of good has been done in that regard. I know Sir Laurence Street is currently the president of an Asian lawyers association. This group of lawyers has become progressively involved in looking at mediation between countries. It is not just a matter of mediation, however; it is also a matter of establishing commonality between the processes of law in this region, particularly commercial law.

The law of contracts where there is an interchange between people needs to be certain, identifiable and commonly interchangeable. There is a great deal that needs to be done in that respect. I know the Indonesians are interested in having consultations with our Australian government officials to see to what degree they can identify our legal systems in the commercial sense. I believe that could well extend over a wider basis.

A great deal of good has been achieved from the Bogor meeting and the statement by the Prime Minister. However, I will spend my remaining time on the downside of two other matters. I think it is important that we understand, in the same way as the Thais have reservations about the identity and purpose of APEC, the general attitude of Asian countries on many issues. I think the comments of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) about the Khmer Rouge in Thailand is a very good example of how at times the aggressiveness, for which we are characteristic, can bring the wrong result.

To my mind the tragedy was the way in which the statement was made. No foreign minister and no Prime Minister can afford to be too arrogant and not take into account the sensitivities of a country, either because of the nature of its religion or prejudices or because it feels it will lose face, by making attack in the wrong way. The sad part is that now the foreign minister has virtually retracted his comments about Thai support for the Khmer Rouge it is he who has lost face. Australia has lost face in an area that is of great concern to this country.

We all want to see the elections that led to a change of regime within Cambodia, the outcome of the commitment of UNTAC forces which led to the elections and the efforts by Australians, including General Sanderson, in the sponsored UN peacekeeping force come to a positive result. It is no use going out there approaching the issue like a bull at a gate. We need to have the lesson of the Minister for Foreign Affairs' remarks in our mind when we look at future relations within APEC. Certainly in Thailand there is great concern about the effect those statements have made on our future relationship. We do not want those sorts of statements used in future approaches we may take within the APEC context.

The other concern I have is that we do not set out in any way to think this is something that is going to be just a short-term endeavour. The Prime Minister in his statement certainly has suggested that it is going to be a way in which we can provide a better world in the 21st century.

We should remember that the beginnings of Bogor were in 1956 when the Japan-Australia trade agreement was entered into. The person who I feel more than anybody else has been responsible for this initiative is the late Sir John Crawford. John Crawford, who was head of the department of trade and industry when I first came to this place, was one who certainly saw the need for us to be able to develop new relationships in this Asia-Pacific region.

We need to understand that while our economies are moving ahead—those of Asia are in particular—there is another dimension to trying to develop peace in the world. That entails looking after those countries in which the same opportunity is not present. I think it is important that, as we look at the Asia-Pacific, we look also at the Indian Ocean where it is said that a similar association may be developed. I think that may be very much in Australia's interests. Sadly, the countries of Africa and the countries of South America still have a long way to go before the opportunities available in Asia are available for them.

In all, I commend the Prime Minister and the Australian government for the role they have played in the pursuit of the APEC initiatives and trust that, as the Prime Minister has suggested, they will be a basis for continued multilateral dialogue into the 21st century.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very interesting speech by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). It was good to see him commending the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and I join with him in doing so. One of the striking things about Australian history is the slowness with which we have recognised the importance of our geographic location. We are predominantly an immigrant people, predominantly from Europe. For that reason, the countries to which many Australians have related have been in Europe and then, at the time of the Second World War, the United States.

PARA.TAB: Throughout history, there have been prophetic people who have recognised the importance of our geographic location in relation to Asia and have tried to build up our relationships with that enormous continent. The right honourable member for New England referred to John Crawford as one of those, but there have been many. One thinks of scientists like Sir Ian Clunies-Ross or scholars like McMahon Ball. Jim Cairns's book Living with Asia influenced my development and concern in this area. There have been people on both sides of this House. R.G. Casey, when minister for foreign affairs, was very committed to building up relations with Asia and the Colombo Plan was one part of that.

That earlier investment is now bearing great fruit in our very good relationships with Asia. In the last few years, that firm foundation has been built on very effectively by the government—by the previous Prime Minister and by the present Prime Minister—in establishing strong economic relationships with the rapidly growing Asian countries. The APEC idea, which originated in Asia, has been gradually, methodically and carefully developed at a moderate, proper rate, depending on the sound consultation which has taken place. The meeting in Bogor was a very important stage along the way to greater integration with the countries of Asia.

The Bogor agreement is a very important one. I simply repeat what others have already said in this debate: the negotiation of an agreement that there should be free and open trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific region by the year 2020 is a major achievement. By making the target date well ahead, countries are given plenty of time to adjust, to make the changes in their tariff and non-tariff barrier structures, to be able to achieve that goal. The target is also expressed in a way which gives greater time for the developing countries to make their adjustments. The target is set for 2010 for the industrialised countries and 2020 for the developing countries. That ensures that the greater difficulty of developing countries in achieving that target is fully recognised.

There are a number of other achievements from the Bogor meeting which have received less attention. Some of them were referred to by the right honourable member for New England, but I would like to rehearse them because they are less well known than is the goal of reduction of tariffs. One of the most important is the elimination of administrative and other impediments in areas such as customs, standards, investment and other non-tariff barriers to trade. It is very important in order to facilitate effective trade relationships that we try to standardise on our procedures, on our investment guidelines, and that that quite complex task be addressed now so that it can be achieved as quickly as possible.

In order to ensure that these goals are not an excuse for delaying reductions in tariffs, the Bogor meeting also agreed to accelerate within the region the elimination of tariffs relating to the Uruguay Round so that they would be implemented in the time that was set for them, so that those commitments are applied as well as those within the APEC region. As well, there was a commitment which would prevent any further increases in tariff or non-tariff barriers in a way that would hardly seem necessary. But, of course, it is quite important to express that minimum standard as well as the positive goal.

As well as those very important developments relating to tariffs, there were a number of other important achievements, involving integrating the business sector into APEC programs, creating a mechanism for that purpose and establishing a review procedure for considering a voluntary consultative dispute mediation service. It is wrapped around with qualifications but, provided that is implemented, that too could be an important step forward.

I was particularly glad to see that there was a commitment relating to human resource development. I share the concern of the right honourable member for New England that social issues were not at all prominent on the agenda. That is understandable; it is not a criticism at all. Economic development is certainly the priority for the region, but one would like to see APEC expand its attention in other centrally important areas of government policy, and those in the social policy area are amongst them. That would obviously include education and health very high on the agenda. There was a mention of those in relation to human resource development and cooperation relating to that. I strongly support that at the next meeting greater attention be given to that cooperative educational activity and hope to expand it into other areas, such as health and housing.

There was also a commitment to strengthening dialogue on economic policy questions other than tariffs. That, too, is crucial. One of the striking features of the global economy at present is that there is no global forum at which economic policy can be comprehensively discussed. The G7 relates only to the major industrialised countries, the OECD relates to western industrialised countries, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank principally deal with current account deficit developing countries, and the UN has very little influence.

It is very important that we build up one global forum where economic policy questions can be comprehensively and influentially discussed. That should happen through the economic and social council of the United Nations, but a step towards that goal would be to build up regional discussion of those questions. That is happening in Europe. That is one of the central aspects of the importance of the European Union. It should also happen in our region. There is scope for coordination of macro-economic policy, for example, for examining ways within the region of standardising approaches to taxation to prevent the competitive downward bidding of tax rates which foreign investors sometimes force on to weak, developing countries.

There are many areas where cooperation over economic policy would enhance the economic development prospects of developing countries as well as industrialised countries in the region. That should be on the APEC agenda. Another issue I would hope would fit onto the APEC agenda in due course is that of security. One of the major steps that has been important in Europe in the last couple of decades has been the establishment of the conference on security and cooperation, which has led to improved communication about defence issues within Europe. It has led to the introduction of a whole series of confidence building measures to improve communication so that those countries can build up their trust in each other, reduce a breakdown of communications, which leads to tension, and allow them to reduce their military expenditure below what it would otherwise be.

The same kind of communication does not yet effectively exist within the east Asia region. It would be a very important step to gradually move in that direction. This year is notable for our having the first conference on security matters in the east Asia region. That was held in the middle of the year. Just the fact that it was held is a very significant development. Three years ago, I moved a motion in this House calling for the establishment of a conference on security and cooperation in east Asia and the Pacific. The opposition opposed that motion on the grounds that it was too visionary, that it was inconsistent with Australian interest in some way or that the Americans did not like it. Now it is supporting that approach. That change has occurred within the last three years.

The US is supporting that kind of approach because, obviously, it makes sense. If we are not talking to each other, we are creating a situation where tension increases. If we are communicating effectively, tension can be reduced, potential military conflict can be defused and we can spend rather less on wasteful military activity and build up our expenditure on far more important economic and social programs. I hope that security will also appear on the APEC agenda in due course and that there will be some place on that agenda for human rights questions. They are difficult, they involve tension, and there are different perspectives in different countries but, quite clearly, Australia has a commitment to enhancing and strengthening human rights within the region. There are some notable cases of failure to apply appropriate human rights standards within the region, and it is very important that we play our role on a principled, firm and determined basis in strengthening implementation of human rights, both in the political and legal spheres and the economic, social and cultural spheres.

It is interesting that, on the agenda for the World Summit for Social Development, for which preparations are being made in New York and which will be held in Copenhagen next year, one of the issues receiving a great deal of attention is the ratification universally of the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights and the strengthening implementation of that convention. It will be a fine convention because it will set minimum standards for the availability of education and health and the goal of full employment.

There is strong support for that convention in Australia. In fact, an Australian chairs the international implementation committee. We are advocating, in the preparations for the world summit, that that covenant be universally ratified by the year 2000 and that resources available for its implementation be increased and strengthened. That will also play a role in strengthening human rights regimes in Asia. It is important that human rights appear on the agenda of regional bodies as well as the UN in order to ensure that those goals are achieved.

I congratulate the Prime Minister, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and all associated with the Bogor meeting. It was a major achievement. It is a very important step towards greater economic integration in the region. We look forward to making that more fruitful and effective in the years ahead. We also hope and advocate that the agenda for future APEC meetings be extended in those social, security and human rights areas so that total relationships within the region can be effectively strengthened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to speak on the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on APEC. Our future lies with Asia, which is what this particular paper is all about. Earlier today we discussed the defence white paper, Defending Australia, and this flows on from that. Both those matters are very much inter-related when it comes to speaking about Australia's future, particularly in this region.

PARA.TAB: I think all of us in this parliament need to be positive in our approach to dealing with these sorts of issues in our area. I was particularly disappointed to hear some comments from those opposite and to read in the paper of the attitude of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer). The headline I read was something like `Downer tears up white paper'. That has been his attitude for some time. I remember at the last election he visited my electorate as the opposition spokesperson on defence—my vote went up two points, so he can come back any time—and made it quite clear that, if the opposition were elected to government, it would not be going ahead with the purchase of further F111s. The good thing for the defence of Australia was that those opposite were not elected to government.

We now have 15 extra F111s which have been refurbished and are now flying. It was certainly a great initiative of the government to purchase them. That goes hand in hand with what we need when talking about defending Australia. The APEC agreement is very important, and I think we all need to get behind it. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) was much more positive in his comments on the Prime Minister's participation in the APEC meeting and the Bogor declaration.

The central element in the Declaration of Common Resolve is the commitment to free trade and investment in the region by the year 2010 for industrialised economies and by the year 2020 for developing economies. What underpins that commitment is our recognition of the growing independence of regional economies and the need to work together to maintain high rates of economic growth. That work must start here if we are to expand that into the Asia region as well. Our business community plays a very important part in that.

There has been some criticism that business has not been as active as it should be. Whilst the government is committed to the APEC process, we need to urge business and the community to get behind the process. BHP is a very good example. For some years, it has been supplying specialised building materials designed for particular environmental conditions in the region which are notorious for their effect in the traditional dwellings of areas like Sarawak. BHP is taking a positive step. The number of Australian companies making a name for themselves in the Asia-Pacific region is growing, but it may be too slow. We need to encourage it more.

For industry to really succeed in the region, it does not simply need to identify and tap into an export market in selected countries. Industry has to pursue a real commitment to the region and its people. I was pleased to pick up the September edition of the Business Council Bulletin out of all the mountains of paper that come to our offices in this place. This edition had the heading `Asia Pacific Economic Developments'. When business is picking up and running with this, the sorts of criticisms I just made will be picked up, because there are great opportunities. There is a special feature in this publication about Mr Bob Lim, the Business Council's director of policy analysis and research. The executive director's forward said:

SPEECH.PARA: This article was written by Bob Lim following a recent study tour of several regional economies where he met with government ministers, officials, bankers, economists, academics and business people.

PARA.TAB: Bob Lim's visit sought to address the question: "Can government policies and corporate strategies in Australia assume that Asia Pacific growth will proceed on the same basis as the past two decades?" His answer is a resounding "Yes"! In particular, he said that this assessment echoes the sentiments expressed in an October 1993 survey by The Economist (A Survey of Asia; A Billion Consumers).

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to say:

By 2000, Asians . . . are expected to account for 3.5 billion of the world's 6.2 billion people. On conservative assumptions, fully 1 billion of those Asians—not much less than the entire populations of north America, South America and the European Community today—will be living in households with some consumer-spending power (meaning they can buy at least basic goods such as colour televisions, refrigerators and motor-bikes).
Sometimes you wonder what basic goods are. It further goes on to say:

Perhaps 400 million of these consumers—three times as many as now—will have disposable incomes at least equal to the rich-world average today; they will be spending their money on houses, cars, holidays, health care and education. And if all this consumer spending is to take place, immense investments in infrastructure will be needed to make it possible: Power plants, roads and airports among other things. The rocket-like growth and absolute size of Asia's middle class should therefore create some of the biggest business and financial opportunities in history, and far-sighted western firms and their workers stand to profit immensely from this.
That shows the very positive attitude and the focus of the Australian business community. We need more of that and we need the business community to pick that up and run with it.

PARA.TAB: When I was speaking the other day on the defence white paper, I made reference to the trip I made to New Zealand last week and the fact that I do not think Australian business is taking up all the opportunities there either. It is focusing on a lot of the bigger areas, and that is good, but it also has to make sure that it develops and looks at some of the smaller areas—not that New Zealand is one of the smaller ones when we start looking at the South Pacific area, particularly. As the right honourable member for New England said earlier, our two countries have a close relationship and it should be maintained and enhanced at every opportunity. I hope that our visit did achieve that, because we certainly were treated very well by the New Zealanders and I thank them very much for that.

There are opportunities in the other smaller countries such as Samoa, Tonga and the Cook Islands, et cetera, which businesses need to get into. This is an opportunity for us to encourage business as much as we can. I welcome the Business Council Bulletin publication. I am not usually one of the people who get up here and say good things about the Business Council, but I think its members can really pick up on that and do a lot with it. The Bogor declaration definitely gives business many great opportunities in the immediate and long-term future up to the year 2020. What that means is many job opportunities for Australians, which is very important to us. The article also mentioned an exhibition when they were speaking about the growth of the cities. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Year 2000 there will be 22 mega-cities in the world . . . 13 of these cities will be in the Asia-Pacific region
The growth in this region will be quite phenomenal and all of those opportunities are there for us to pick up. Hopefully, we will be able to do that.

PARA.TAB: The APEC summit has been described as an overwhelming opportunity for everybody and it has been important for us. The Prime Minister is to be commended on his contribution to that. He has certainly shown his leadership qualities. It is something that we on this side of the House are very proud of and I know all Australians can be very proud of his participation and of what he has done in these particular areas. There are those great opportunities for us. The Prime Minister made the point the other day in his speech—I mentioned the New Zealanders before—that the APEC summit was a triumph for diplomacy. The Prime Minister of New Zealand, Mr Bolger, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the level of commitment from leaders was remarkable. . . it is truly going to change the nature of trade in the world in the next five years.

The overwhelmingly positive comments that have come from the various APEC leaders mirror this attitude. That sort of feeling and attitude are essential if we are going to succeed in the part of the world where we actually belong. This makes it even more important for Australian business to go into the region, because industries of the other member nations will not stand still—nor should they. I call on Australian industry, particularly those businesses with established export markets in the region, to make the most of the multitude of opportunities the Bogor declaration has created for them.

PARA.TAB: Although the government's policies are changing Australia for the better, there is always more to be done and we will continue as a government to keep up the strength of Australia today. Australia is finishing this year on a very positive note, with the growth we are seeing at present. As time goes on, we must recognise the need for further changes and improvements across all sectors of the economy. One particular thing that Australians are good at is our ability to trade in services. That is a very important area that we should pick up on.

When it comes to employment, technology is something that has often been seen as a bit of a problem for us. How do we cope with the new technologies as they move on? Of course, we could have done things better, but technology is something that has a major impact. There are also great advantages for us in that area. We should make sure that we use all our comparative advantages in the areas of technology and education to increase our trade participation in the region. Our health and education services are something that we can really participate in and we can offer more in training services. The telecommunications industry is going ahead in leaps and bounds.

In my own electorate, a new information technology outlet is opening today. If I had been at home, I would have gone to the opening, but, unfortunately, I am still here. We are taking advantage of new information links. The new outlet in my electorate is called Infolink. A group in New Zealand, the Wellington City Council, is involved in the same sort of thing. It is helping us in Ipswich with our participation. There was a seminar here earlier today on that very aspect. The New Zealanders were over here helping us develop these new information technologies. They are the sorts of things that are happening and the sorts of things we need to focus on if we want to play our part and take every opportunity that is available to us as a nation in terms of APEC. I know business has the ability to do it and it really needs to take every opportunity to do that.

In conclusion, we need to ensure that we on this side of the House and those on the other side of the House are very positive about the opportunities that are available to us in the booming Asia-Pacific region. We on this side will continue to pursue those opportunities as much as we can. I am sure that as time goes on we will have every opportunity to take up those opportunities, which will help employment and help the Australian people prosper. I hope that this will be the last time I speak in the House this year. I take the opportunity to wish all my colleagues the best for the festive season and I look forward to seeing them all back here next year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a much appreciated gesture of the government to allow those of us who have missed out on the opportunity to speak in the adjournment debate during the past week or fortnight the opportunity to put a few things on the public record this afternoon. I want to address two issues in this adjournment debate. Firstly, I would like to put on record the concerns of an orchid grower within my electorate of Lyne, Mr John Wright of Coopernook. Mr Wright has serious concerns with the continued use of the chemical fungicide Benlate throughout Australia other than in South Australia.

PARA.TAB: The use of Benlate as a chemical fungicide has been the cause of widespread litigation in the United States of America and has been withdrawn from the market in South Australia due to damage caused to the flower growing industry in that state. One Florida newspaper has described the story of Benlate as a tale without equal in modern agriculture. Benlate is the trade name for a fungicide that is labelled for use on a wide range of fruit and vegetable crops and ornamental plants.

Benlate is manufactured by the multinational giant Dupont, and the wettable powder formulation came on to the market in 1969. In late 1987 Dupont replaced Benlate WP with an easier to mix granular formulation, Benlate DF. Both have been commonly used in Australia, and for many years Benlate was a staple for nursery growers to prevent fungal outbreaks. However, over the last few years, Benlate has been linked to health problems and to plant damage in the United States, England, New Zealand and Australia.

Since 1991 there has been a recognition that the product Benlate has produced deleterious effects in crops and that serious problems exist. The dry flowerable granular forms of the fungicide—Benlate 50DF, Benlate 1991 DF and Tersan 1991 DF—were removed from the market in the United States in March 1991 when Dupont issued a stop sale and recall on these products. This followed reports of stunted root and plant growth. Benlate DF was then recalled in Australia following notification in a press release dated 12 June 1991. However, the recall was not at all well publicised. Yet the wettable powder formulation, Benlate WP, is still on sale in Australia. However, there is evidence that this formulation has also caused problems in plants.

Mr John Wright of Coopernook claims it was the product Benlate that recently totally wiped out his orchid crop costing him in excess of $100,000. The history of Mr Wright's problem is an interesting one. He has made extensive representations to the New South Wales agriculture department and to Dupont Australia regarding this issue. So much so that at various times representatives from both organisations have visited Mr Wright's property to takes samples for testing.

I therefore have some serious concerns to raise in this debate. Why, in a letter dated 25 October 1992 from the National Registration Authority—the group that is supposed to monitor all chemical products in Australia—does it state:
In all states, except South Australia, no reports of plant damage have been received by departments of agriculture/ primary industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wright has had samples taken from his property by the New South Wales department of agriculture, yet it seems to have forgotten having visited his property. It is highly irregular that South Australia has been the only state in Australia that has been able to force Dupont Australia and the relevant department to withdraw Benlate from the market. I am sure the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) would agree with me that what is dangerous in one state must also be considered dangerous in another. Uniformity across the states of Australia is surely lacking here.

PARA.TAB: My next concern is with the testing arrangements for Benlate. I do not have a superior knowledge of herbicides, but I understand that Benlate is a promoter of sulfonel urea, which is a herbicide of sorts. Naturally, after finding out this information, Mr Wright wanted sulfonel urea tested out on his plants. However, just this week the New South Wales agriculture department has told him that it does not have the facilities to test it. This is very strange indeed.

There is yet another concern in this issue. I have here two newspaper articles from the Newcastle Morning Herald, one headlined `Avocado dip a recipe for longer life produce' and the other `Fruit chemical mistake admitted'. What happened was that a fellow in New South Wales agriculture department thought he had discovered another use for Benlate as a preserver for avocados. The five-member team claimed to have spent four years developing the technique and the federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy had applied to the New Zealand government to allow in exports using the new procedure. Yet in a following newspaper article, this same fellow is forced to admit he was wrong—that the chemical would actually seep through the skin and cause serious physical problems!

Yet another strange twist to this story is that when Mr Wright made his initial inquiries to Dupont Australia regarding Benlate, Dupont employed a consultant to speak with Mr Wright and take samples. This person just so happened to be the wife of the representative who thought he had come up with the miracle avocado dip for the New South Wales department of agriculture.

There are too many unanswered questions about the active ingredients of Benlate; there are too many unanswered questions surrounding the use of this chemical by Australian farmers; and there are too many unanswered questions about the role of certain individuals with what seems to be an ulterior motive for the protection of Benlate for this issue to simply rest. We need to see this issue investigated by the department of primary industries in a hope of achieving some uniform dangerous chemical practices throughout Australia. It is only then that individual businessmen, such as Mr Wright, who has suffered great personal expense and loss of income, will be protected in their horticultural endeavours.

The second issue I raise in this adjournment debate is totally unrelated to that of the chemical Benlate, but it is very important considering that in 1995 we are coming to the Australian celebrations for the 50th anniversary of the ending of the Second World War. I want to put on the public record what took place in my home town of Wingham on Remembrance Day a couple of weeks ago.

An important ceremony was held on Remembrance Day in November this year in final recognition for the young soldier from Wingham, Private Alan `Johnny' Wallis, who gave his life in Vietnam—the only native of Wingham on the mid-north coast of New South Wales to lose his life in that Vietnam conflict. The ceremony, which included 10 diggers from his section who fought alongside him, as well as members from the Manning District Vietnam Veterans Association, unveiled a plaque in his memory at the Wingham Town Hall.

Private Alan J. Wallis was killed in Vietnam on 16 May 1968—26 years ago. It has taken that long, as we have seen over the last couple of years, for the broader community in Australia to develop respect for those people that were involved in the Vietnam conflict. He is survived by his aunt, Vera Tisdell, and his nephew, Alan Bell, who both unveiled the plaque at the ceremony and accepted replicas of the young soldier's medals, as well as the Australian flag, which I presented to them on behalf of the Commonwealth.

His section commander, Bert `Shorty' Thirkell, gave a short tribute to the young soldier who died in the battle of Fire Support Base Coral. I might add at this point that none other than the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) was also involved as a Vietnam veteran in that battle. There were unashamedly few dry eyes among his old buddies. They had travelled from Sydney, Armidale and from up the coast to be there for the special occasion.

For a number of people, including local veteran Steve Pemberton, the unveiling of the plaque was a final farewell at the end of a long campaign and research to have recognition for the only solider from Wingham to die in the Vietnam War. Steve deserves to be congratulated for his efforts and the hours that he put into researching the story of Johnny Wallis.

For many of the veterans present, including Private Wallis's mates from 7 Section, 3 Platoon, 1RAR, the day was filled with memories of the sacrifices and the comradeship which no-one but those who went to Vietnam could understand. Special mention must also be made of Private Wallis's friend and digger mate Eric Edmonds. I understand Eric had been absolutely determined to be at the ceremony on Remembrance Day 1994, on that Friday. However, he unfortunately passed away in Concord Hospital on 28 October this year after his battle with cancer.

One of the Vietnam veterans at that short ceremony for Johnny Wallis told me about some of the ongoing statistics and the problems that are faced by Vietnam veterans today. I was handed a copy of Stand to, a bulletin put out by the Vietnam Veterans Association. An interesting paragraph in there stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The statistics from the Vietnam War are horrifying. Of the 50,000 troops who served in the theatre, 5,000 have died from "natural causes", over 4,000 have suicided, some 16,000 are being treated for varying disabilities, of these 16,000, a large number have Post Traumatic Stress Disorder. This is a psychiatric disorder which is most distressing to wives and families and the members who have it. The veteran looks 100% but is in fact a very disturbed individual. In the last "Veterans Budget Review", the DVA set aside four foolscap pages alone on this matter.

Those statistics are very compelling as to the circumstances of a large percentage of the Vietnam veterans—those 50,000 soldiers who fought on behalf of the Australian community in Vietnam. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the vital problems that face my electorate is the question of education. Some statistics from the 1991 census are indicative of the reality out there. Whereas in the Sydney metropolitan area 3 1/2 per cent of people are currently engaged in CAE or university studies, the local figure for the Reid electorate is 2 1/2 per cent. In a similar fashion, one finds that, whilst about eight per cent of Reid residents have higher education or associate diploma qualifications, that compares with the figure of approximately 15 per cent for the Sydney region. These figures are indicative of a problem that relates to the presence of a very large NESB population and the socioeconomic characteristics of low income levels and high unemployment, equally enforced to some degree by the starvation of resources in the library sector by the Parramatta City Council, whose performance is in strong contrast to Auburn which recently obtained an award for its work in ethnic libraries.

PARA.TAB: But today I want to talk about a study that came out in the last week or so—it was cited in the Age on 5 December this year—by Dr Bob Birrell and Ian Dobson. It noted the very high probability that Australia's Austudy scheme is being abused in a very big fashion not only by people undertaking tax minimisation schemes but also by a number of people resident outside of Australia who have children studying here. They went to the fact that large numbers of people in the private education field are currently receiving Austudy, despite paying school fees of approximately $7,000 a year. They are questioning how people can afford this $7,000 and at the same time have incomes which qualify them for Austudy.

The main point that concerns me is the interrelationship of this with the access to our university system by tourists and visitors. In the last few months I have had need to correspond with universities around Australia, as well as their conference. Although I do not go down the street looking for such people or asking people questions, in a very short time at least three people came to my attention, through migration cases, who have been merrily attending our universities while tourists in this country.

They have not come here in the proper way as foreign students and abided by the variety of requirements in that field, such as having student visas and departing from Australia at the time of expiry of their visas, the maintenance of a valid enrolment and a maximum of 20 hours part-time work. They have not come here and sought to enter our institutions up front, paying the fees and abiding by the rules. In one case a person was simultaneously undertaking tertiary study for three years while pursing a refugee claim. In that process she had a solicitor with the effrontery to put forward as one of the grounds for residence in this country the fact that she had illegally done a course in this country.

The universities supposedly have some responsibility in this field. Under section 5.21 of the Administrative guidelines manual for higher education institutions on HECS and fees it notes that they are supposed to confirm the eligibility of students who claim exemption from HECS and to verify documentation relevant to a student's claim for exemption. Furthermore, the immigration status of students will be clear from passports or other travel documents. Section 5.72 speaks of overseas students and says that they are required to identify themselves as holders of student visas or temporary entry visas.

Essentially a part of this problem is Australia's ludicrous privacy laws which allow people to get tax file numbers without any requirement whatsoever as to their resident status. That in turn becomes a crucial facet of their possibilities of entering institutions here. From my contact with these universities there has been a fairly studied level of disinterest, a cavalier attitude, that really it is too hard for them to check. It would be atrocious of the government to actually require them to check passports and other verification, because they really have too much to do.

Essentially, every year we have pressure in our electorates from students who cannot get admission to courses. Our region has been part of a campaign waged by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and others to seek some kind of reallocation of university places in this country to recognise the population change favouring Queensland, western Sydney and northern New South Wales. That is typical of a very real problem out there, but it does not really assist measures of university access.

At the same time, I feel there is a case that this system is being abused in a far greater fashion than the government or these institutions claim. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) in response to a question earlier this year stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . institutions must satisfy themselves that, in all cases, the students have the correct enrolment status. It is a matter for each higher education institution to decide how best to fulfil its obligations to ensure that students are enrolled according to the correct status.

TALK.START.PARA: —But do they?
—As queried over there, the rampant attitude of these institutions is that they do not check. The comment of the University of New South Wales, for instance, is:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst we currently rely on students' honesty when completing application and enrolment forms, we believe that appropriate sanctions are available if students do make a false declaration. Alternative procedures such as demanding to see passports or birth certificates before enrolling 24,000 local students would be a huge administrative burden which institutions, with their present state of funding, would not be in a position to bear.
Professor Thom of UNE commented:
My academic colleagues are increasingly concerned by the demands placed on us by government agencies for more and more accountability . . .

The registrar of the Northern Territory University commented that this `would divert scarce resources away from areas of greater need and importance'. Mr F.S. Hambly of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee said that the greater flexibility in the visitor visa provisions has been welcomed. But his solution to all this was, `It is too hard for us to do although we are supposed to do it.' He said:
It would, therefore, be appropriate to bring such cases to the attention the DIEA, DEET and the institution concerned.
He put forward the proposition:
. . . the number of international students who have attempted to defraud the nation by passing themselves off as local students is extremely small.
He comments:

It would need to be demonstrated by hard data rather than hearsay that such fraud is in fact a growing trend, before additional measures to monitor compliance would be considered either appropriate or cost-effective.

I had three people walk into my office within a period of two months. One of them, fortunately, the University of Wollongong had picked up and deprived of his qualifications but he had managed to go along to that institution, like the other claimant I spoke about earlier, for three years undetected simply by saying, `I am a permanent resident.' As I say, this typifies a very real problem out there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like an honour system.
—That is right. As the member over there notes, an honour system. There have been some positive attitudes from a minority of universities. Central Queensland University noted:

SPEECH.PARA: Now that you have highlighted this potential for abuse, we will be more vigilant in monitoring the situation to see if the practice is occurring at this institution.
The University of Wollongong, which I mentioned earlier, stated:

The University of Wollongong first experienced this problem two years ago and has carefully checked the residential status of students enrolling in courses in 1993 and 1994. Students are required to bring to Enrolment either a passport, Birth Certificate, or Citizenship Certificate for verification.

In other words, this university acknowledges the problem, is doing something about it and does not seek to shirk responsibility. Essentially, people get access with tax file numbers, go to a university for a period and then, in some cases, decide to leave Australia before HECS is collected.

PARA.TAB: Essentially, the buck passing between a number of government departments and the universities throughout this country must halt. If we are talking about the failure of Australian students to get access to tertiary education, it is not good enough to simply say that it is too hard, that we have not got the time, that too many of our clerical staff are doing other things. This is, as I said, a manifest problem. It is also typified in my own knowledge of people getting access to TAFE colleges or people getting building licences in New South Wales who are not even permanent residents and who have no migration status that justifies such. I ask the government to take this matter seriously. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I would like to address a subject that is or should be important to all of us: the integrity of the electoral system. With the last federal election being lost by our side of politics by perhaps about 1,000 votes in a very small number of seats, it is in our interest on this side and, I submit respectfully, in the interests of colleagues opposite, to make sure that what is said to be the result of an Australian election accurately represents the collective will of the Australian people. I am not suggesting that the government is out there rorting the system on this matter. I think it is very important that we, as parliamentarians, recognise that we have a responsibility to the Australian community to ensure that there is integrity in our electoral system.
—They misled us with their promises.

—The government has certainly misled the Australian people with its promises prior to the election. I am seeking to point out in the adjournment debate today that it is important when the votes are tallied and the result is called that the result represents what the Australian people wish to achieve on election day.

PARA.TAB: I find it absolutely amazing that in Australia in 1994 we have an honour system for enrolments.
