The honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) mentioned quite accurately that there are major problems with people enrolling through the university system who are not eligible to be in Australia. The universities do not require any evidence of their right to be in Australia before permitting an enrolment to occur.

We also have an honour system for Australian electoral enrolments. If people wanted to rort the electoral system, then they could sit down and fill in many thousands of enrolment cards after the Electoral Office has conducted the habitation survey. Using the envelopes provided by the Australian Electoral Office, they could get thousands of nom de plumes added to any electoral roll. No-one in this House on either side would support such a practice. But it does indicate to me that it is very important that proof of identity be required prior to people being able to get on the electoral roll.

At present, before one is able to open a bank account one must provide 100 points to prove to the financial institution that the person exists. Only real people, not nom de plumes, are able to have bank accounts in Australia. Similarly, the Department of Social Security requires some evidence of who a person is before that person is able to register for unemployment benefits. Even the drivers licence issuing process requires some evidence of identity.

The right to vote in Australia ought to be extended only to those people entitled to enrol. Yet, while we have these fairly stringent provisions to weed out people who are not entitled to have a bank account, to be on social security benefits or to have a drivers licence, we have a situation where anyone who wants to fill in any number of enrolment cards could be enrolled on the Australian electoral roll under any number of nom de plumes. I think that is something the government really ought to look at. It is a matter of grave concern. I suggest that honourable members opposite would also be worried.

There is also a problem that we do not have continual reviews of electoral rolls. I am not blaming the Australian Electoral Office here. I think it has a very difficult job. With the very large mobility factor within Australia, with people moving from the rust belt areas of southern Australia to places like Queensland, we find that there are a great number of changes to enrolments. After a habitation survey is completed there is absolutely no check on the very large number of new enrolments or changed enrolments which arrive at the Electoral Office just prior to an election.

I understand that in 1993, in the seven days prior to the close of rolls, almost half a million people changed their enrolments or sought enrolment. Again, the honour system applies to these people. They are automatically placed on the electoral roll without checking their identity, age, citizenship or their right to be on that roll. With only about 1,000 people in a selected small number of electorates across Australia determining the election result, it is pretty obvious that the present system is open to rorting and rigging. That is a matter of very grave concern.

We on this side of the chamber would certainly like to see continuous enrolment checking. We would like to see the Electoral Office advertise widely prior to an election period to make sure as many people get on the electoral roll as are entitled to but within a time frame which enables their right to enrol to be checked. I think the last minute rush can create a situation where it is very difficult to check a person's right to enrol even if the Electoral Office is of a mind to do so.

Prior to the 1984 election, we had a subdivisional arrangement within the Australian electorates. In the electorate of Herbert, represented by my friend the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), we had a number of subdivisions. It meant that if a person was going to vote on polling day as an ordinary voter, that person had to vote within the particular subdivision in which he or she was enrolled. If you were going to go from one side of an electorate to another, then obviously you could still cast a vote but you would be an absentee voter. The honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), who is in the chair, would also recall the situation that used to occur.

In country areas in particular where people vote quite often the polling staff recognise them. We now have a situation where a person who has lodged these thousands of nom de plumes could go to any of the 40 or 50 polling booths in any of our federal electorates and vote a number of times as an ordinary voter. If we had the subdivisional system reinstated, it would be less likely that this would occur as often because a person would have to cast an absent vote in areas away from his immediate area of residence. I think that is very important as well.

I would like to touch on another subject that I feel very strongly about. I have supported the principle of voluntary voting in the chamber in the past. I would certainly go to the barricades to defend everyone's right in Australia to enrol and vote on polling day. One of the things we ought to be thankful for in Australia is that we have a democratic system. When an election is called, people are able to go to the polls and vote for the party of their choice or vote to toss the government out.

Our Australian constitution and system of government, with our system of checks and balances, have obviously made sure that we enjoy what we consider, quite rightly, to be a very basic right of democracy. Of course, we only have to turn on our television sets to see that in many other parts of the world similar rights are not enjoyed. But I believe that in a democracy, while it is a person's right to vote, it is the very antithesis of freedom to fine someone if he or she chooses not to vote. I think a person ought to be able to vote for a political party or an individual or against a political party or an individual.

But I also think that, in a democracy, it is very important to ensure that, if a person considers no political party or candidate is worthy of support, that person has the right to abstain. After all, when a vote is called here in the chamber, we have the right to vote one way, the other way or, indeed, to abstain.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a responsibility to vote.

—We have that right, although the discipline on the other side of the chamber is such that, if a person exercises his conscience and votes against the party line, he or she is tossed out. The member opposite ought not to interject. He has a very low regard for the standards of this House. After all, yesterday he wore his noddy hat in here during a division. But, in the spirit of Christmas, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would have noticed that we did not comment on it at that particular time.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important that members of parliament on both sides try to make sure that we have integrity in our electoral system. I am not suggesting that thousands of people lodge nom de plumes or that the rolls are rorted, but the system is open to those things occurring. I think that wherever possible, wherever we see a loophole or the capacity for fraud, we have a responsibility to the Australian people to move to close that loophole or shut off that fraud.

I think the government really ought to take these matters into account. They are vital matters. I am not being partisan in this debate. I think, really, I am speaking on behalf of the Australian people. I also believe that I am expressing the sentiments of probably all members in the chamber. When an election is called, it is important that what is said to be the result does, in fact, represent the collective will of the Australian people. Integrity in the electoral system will make sure that this occurs. After all, in a democracy this must indeed happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter which touches on my electorate only in passing, but which does touch on the Australian nation. I refer to the way that people with serious brain injury are treated within this Commonwealth. Some members on the other side might find that a matter for comment; the member for Cook (Mr Dobie) might think that it is something to laugh about. But I am sure that the families of those people who have been in serious car accidents who have been classified and determined as being in a vegetative state would take his comments and laughter in the light in which they should be taken—they would view them with disdain.

PARA.TAB: I have been approached by a Dr Ted Freeman, who has been recognised internationally and has been invited to join the international working party on the management of the persistent vegetative state. He is the author of a book entitled The Catastrophe of Coma—a way back. Dr Freeman is in many ways a loner in the medical profession; many in the establishment have viewed the work he has done with very cynical attitudes.

I would like us to think about the situation where, through no fault of their own or through fault of their own, people are involved in accidents which cause massive brain damage. Often those people who are thus traumatised end up in a coma. If and when that coma does diminish and they come out of it, their state is diagnosed by the medical profession in terms of their ability to rehabilitate.

It is a sad reflection that a member of such a family has commented, when speaking of a loved one who was in such a position, that the situation went from `intensive care' to `no care' to `don't care'. The reflection is that there is not a great deal of emphasis put on the rehabilitation of these people. If their medical assessment is that they are in a vegetative state from which they are not able to be rehabilitated, then those people are often shunted away to nursing homes.

There are a number of angles to consider at this point. We can first talk about the personal trauma and relationships involved. Many of the families of these victims are told, `This person is a vegetable; turn away, walk away from them; go on with your life and treat them as though they are dead.' While there are many situations where that may be the case and people may be in a non-returnable condition in terms of any communication or cognitive process, there are many, according to Dr Freeman, who are misdiagnosed; in fact, he has suggested that the majority of people are misdiagnosed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you as an individual—and I ask all those in the House to think as individuals—how you would feel if your cognitive processes were there but your ability to communicate, your physical ability to be able to contact the outside world, were not there? It would be the very worst of all imprisonments. It would be the very worst of all solitary confinements. To then have the medical profession advise those who loved them to turn and walk away would be a tragedy for them.

I am led to believe that in other countries, such as the United States, Great Britain and even New Zealand, there is talk of withdrawal of what they call `life support systems'. In these instances, the life support systems which are referred to are stomach-feeding and intravenous drips to keep hydration up. Denial of those things leads ultimately to death. My concern is whether this is done on a humanitarian basis or an economic rationalist basis. It is not done in Australia at this point in time, and I am not aware of it being advocated in Australia at this point.

In other countries ethical protocols have been developed for the medical profession in order to establish how withdrawal can take place. If Dr Freeman is right and the majority of these people who are considered to be in a vegetative state can be brought back to some semblance of control and cognitive thought, in terms of their ability to do some of the smallest things, in terms of life processes, then it is a tragedy that we should avoid at all costs.

Dr Freeman has asked that a national register of coma cases be established. He does this for a number of reasons, the first of which is that, without ongoing support and research dollars in this area, we will find a number of our citizens subjected to this involuntary imprisonment. I cannot think of a worse fate to occur to an individual who has cognitive thought, even though it may lie deep in his or her brain, but who may not be able to communicate with others.

However, Dr Freeman's results, shown in his book and research, show that in many instances these people can be brought back to a state of mind, a state of existence, in which they can experience some of the experiences, the norms of life, that a normal, well bodied adult may achieve, even though they may not be able to appreciate the full range of experiences. It seems to me that we need to address this matter, and to do so with compassion. Dr Freeman suggests that, despite the little research here and the lack of recognition he receives in Australia and in his own country, we are in a position where we are able do a lot more than we presently do.

I very much understand what the National Brain Injury Foundation and Dr Freeman are about. I understand that, whilst these people may not be able to recuperate and rehabilitate themselves to the standard of their former lives, they can achieve great success.

The ability to scratch one's nose or to caress or recognise one's loved ones is all part of that human ability. These people are still human. To be classified as being in a `vegetative state' is virtually one step up from `brain dead'; these people are dehumanised. Some time ago, a film called Coma referred to this and explored the fact that these people were being used as organ banks. I am not suggesting in any way that Australia would go down that path but, if it ever tried to, I would go all the way to make sure it did not happen.

I will address the economic rationalist approach to try to reach those people whose only consideration in any argument on any issue is dollars and cents. The reality is that, once people are diagnosed as being in a vegetative state, the state governments then throw them out of the hospitals into nursing homes. This means a transfer of responsibility from the states to the Commonwealth. That transfer of dollars and cents seems to be pushing people to be declared vegetative and moved across. It takes the responsibility of rehabilitation away from the state and refers it to the Commonwealth. Somebody has to take responsibility. Somebody has to pay. But the cost of rehabilitating these people in many instances is a lot less than the $2 million or $3 million it costs for, say, a 26-year-old to be in a nursing home for the rest of his or her life.

I say to those economic rationalists: look at the dollars and cents approach to rehabilitation. There have been cases where people have become productive members of our society again. From an economic rationalist viewpoint, we should explore every opportunity to get these people out of their comas and give them the fullest life they can achieve. It may not exactly be what we consider to be a full life but, for them and their families, it is an act of humanitarianism. It is an act that we cannot walk away from. It is something we should value, and as human beings we should encourage and do all we can to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two weeks ago I had the privilege of taking a trip through the severely drought affected areas of New South Wales. I visited the towns of Kingscliff, Tyalgum, Kyogle, Coraki, Bonalbo, Armidale, Tamworth, Walcha and the little town of Barraba. It was a most instructive trip. I would certainly recommend that my colleagues in this place take such a trip to enhance their understanding of what is going on in rural and regional Australia today in some of the most severely drought affected areas this country has seen for a very long time.

PARA.TAB: In the face of a disaster, which some of the older people in the community related to me was like returning to wartime conditions and worse, the spirit in those communities was really quite amazing. I could not help but reflect that, if some in this chamber displayed the guts, the determination, the compassion and the generosity that was displayed in some of those communities, Australia would indeed be a lot better off.

They are experiencing such harsh conditions that even the basic necessities of life are not available to them. Many of them are having to rely on charity in order to survive. It is, indeed, heartbreaking. It really was a lump-in-the-throat, heart-wrenching experience for me and my staff who accompanied me. Not only have they experienced several years of severe drought; they have also had to endure a government which has no regard for them and has not considered them at all in a disaster relief program. Many in some of the towns I visited do not qualify for any drought aid but have experienced severe drought over a sustained period of time.

The current rural crisis, which has been brought about by the extended and most debilitating drought in recent memories, has also highlighted the desperate circumstances that many of these rural families are experiencing. For the women in particular—who have multiple roles during this time of wife, mother, carer, community worker, business partner or operator of small businesses in their own right—the impact has been reflected in a deterioration in physical and mental health of their families and of themselves. Women are carrying additional burdens as they take up the hard labour on the farm alongside their partners to keep things going.

For the women who have had these multiple roles, there is evidence of some very serious problems emerging in a social sense. The pressures being exerted on rural women are exacerbated by what I think is a callous disregard of their plight and a somewhat cynical view of delivering aid to drought affected areas. Assistance measures that have been implemented have been too little and too late. The areas that have been lucky enough to qualify for drought relief should have been getting that assistance two years ago. The flow-on effects of the government's tardy consideration of the social and economic consequences of this drought were evident in every community I visited. Women I met with and listened to provided the same assessment of the degradation of life in their communities.

In Tamworth, I met with a group of 20 business and professional women from the town who recognised that, despite the tough times for those people in the town, the women on the rural properties had it even tougher. Those on the land were having to truck in their drinking water, which meant that there was no water to do the weekly laundry. The women of Tamworth got together and offered their washing machines to the women on the land so that each week those women could do their baskets of laundry in the homes of the women of Tamworth.

I do not think we have any idea of what that must be like. As we sit in the comfort of this place and see the wonderful gardens and lawns that surround us, it is very difficult for us to build that picture of hardship in those communities. It was depressing to see the result of the inaction of the government and the reduction of many women to being totally reliant on charitable assistance and welfare programs for even the most basic necessities of life. For our national government to be ignorant of and neglect the desperate social predicament of such a large and proud section of the community is, indeed, a national disgrace.

Some likened the conditions to wartime, and some of the conditions that I saw are akin to those being experienced in Third World countries. That is not what I would have expected from contemporary Australia. While rural women may not be the Labor Party's natural constituents, they and their families deserve much better.

The list of issues that are of concern to Australia's rural women is a litany of Labor's ineptitude, inaction and abdication of its responsibility to women. It is rural and regional women who have delivered so much to the development of this nation and who have received so little recognition for that great contribution.

The lack of income in rural towns is impacting on employment and career opportunities not only for women but also for their families. As a consequence, basic services have been scaled down, rescheduled or withdrawn and the fabric of these towns is rapidly disintegrating. Small business is suffering and education facilities are under threat as families are forced to leave many areas in order to obtain work.

In Casino, one woman put it to a meeting I attended that this government is prepared to pay young people to run away from home via the youth homeless allowance, yet many of these families suffering great hardship were unable to access Austudy to send their children to school. Health and welfare services and the attendant support infrastructure is, in many instances, no longer capable of satisfying the needs of women and their families who remain in these communities. Family instability is a consequence of a lack of communication between partners, and the increased levels of violence and conflict is being exacerbated by this government's disregard of the social impact and by its failure to offer meaningful assistance to the rural communities.

Many women are now confronted with the prospect of greatly diminished access to comprehensive health and welfare services for their families. At a time when financial circumstances are exerting extreme physical and mental stress on families and communities, the prospect of diminished health care services increases those levels of stress, particularly on women and children. For families whose source of income is either greatly diminished or totally dependent on charitable organisations, the additional cost is simply an intolerable burden.

For rural women, the lack of adequate child-care and community support facilities means that women have no respite from the pressures that they are currently experiencing. The challenge of having to maintain their family structure and at the same time provide valuable support to their partner, both on the farm and off the farm, is making life very difficult indeed.

The impact of reduced incomes on families reliant on primary production is influencing the quality and level of educational services available in many regions. The figures are quite dramatic in terms of young people from the country being able to access university and higher education courses compared with young people within the city and urban areas of Australia. The bottom line impact is more upheaval and more pressure, added costs to already strained budgets and increased stress on and dislocation of families who are forced to try to cope with the costs associated with educating children in environments removed from their community.

Career options for both women and their children are suffering enormously as employment opportunities in small businesses—both rural and non-rural—are in many instances no longer available. The list of issues of concern to rural women goes on. Unfortunately, so does this Labor government's procrastination on the important social issue facing Australia today.

I visited only a small area of New South Wales. The distressing fact is that this scenario of women and children being needlessly placed under extreme pressure is being repeated throughout New South Wales and Queensland. We are beginning to see other states, including my own state, enter this scenario.

Women are desperately trying to help preserve the structure and the threads of their families and their communities. They are not looking for handouts. These are proud people. These are people who have great courage, great fortitude and a great ability to just get on and do the job. However, it is well past time when they should have received support. Labor's report card on its consideration, understanding and resolution of the rural crisis and its impact on women must surely read, `Failed to apply the necessary application to the subject; remedial classes highly recommended.'

TALK.START.PARA: —The year 1995 will be the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War. As our country gears up to commemorate this important event, I would like to place on record my sincere congratulations to and commendation of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca) for the program that he has outlined for Australia to participate in the 50th anniversary commemoration next year.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will be aware of the program called Australia Remembers 1945 to 1995, which is an initiative of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs which is very strongly supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the members of the government and, I understand, members of the opposition too. What is important about the Australia Remembers commemoration is that it is not just going to be a series of very large-scale national events where the nation's leaders are involved in important celebrations. It will not just be a series of events involving state leaders in various states. It is also going to be very much a community based program of events.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has facilitated the capacity for local communities to be involved in commemorating the 50th anniversary of the end of the Second World War through his program of local community funding. He has allocated funds to every federal member in Australia and encouraged all federal members to be involved in planning a program of local activities involving their local communities—

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It is a very important allocation of $20,000 per federal electorate. That has been very warmly received by communities across Australia to enable them to be involved in this very valuable program. I have established a Moreton commemorative committee which has been working for the last three months to develop a program of events to ensure that our local community in my federal electorate of Moreton is fully involved in the program of activities next year.

PARA.TAB: I would like to place on record my personal thanks to the members of my committee for the hard work that they have put in already and for the hard work that they will be putting in over the next few months as we plan a number of events. I have been very well served by a number of important local community leaders who are involved in the Moreton commemorative committee for Australia Remembers. I have involved representatives from local RSL sub-branches. Mr Toby Fenton and Mr Frank Pitt from the Holland Park-Mount Gravatt RSL sub-branch have been very valuable members of my committee, as has Mr Bob Taylor, who is the president of the Sunnybank sub-branch of the RSL. Bob Taylor is an important member of my committee because he is also on the Queensland state committee for Australia Remembers and is able to give a dual perspective in our discussions about what we will be doing next year.

I have also made sure that I have representatives from other institutions or organisations in my electorate. Three of those people come from the education sector—Ms Roz Korkatsis, who is a head of department at Mount Gravatt State High School; Geoff Mill, who is the principal of Greenslopes State School; and Graeme Mellor, who is from the Catholic Education Office in Brisbane. They are ensuring that my local schools are very heavily involved in the Australia Remembers campaign.

We also have a very able representative from the War Widows Guild. Mrs Joan Stephenson has been a great source of information, advice and support. We have local government representatives. We have two Brisbane City Council councillors. Councillor Mark Bailey, the councillor for Moorooka, and Councillor Gail McPherson, the councillor for Runcorn, have made very important contributions and given very direct support to our work.

Two military institutions are also involved. I have only two small military facilities in the electorate of Moreton. One of those is a very important facility; that is, the Yeronga District Military Hospital. Lieutenant Alison Denning is a member of my committee. She represents the officer in command of Yeronga hospital. She has been of great assistance.

The other facility in my electorate is the Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital, which from 6 January next year becomes the Greenslopes Private Hospital. The sale of Greenslopes has been confirmed and it has been sold to the Ramsay Health Care Group. Mr Robert Glynn, who has been appointed to manage Greenslopes hospital, is also a member of my committee and is actively involved. As you can see, it is quite a comprehensive committee; it is quite a well based and broadly based committee. The members have been very forthright in their contribution of ideas and suggestions as to how we can get involved.

For the benefit of the House, I will outline the four main themes of next year's commemorations for Australia Remembers. The first important theme is commemoration, which is paying tribute to those who contributed either as service personnel or by keeping our local community and the war effort going. The second is celebration, which is recapturing the joy of and commitment to peace. That is very important. It is 50 years since the end of the Second World War. It has been 50 years of peace. The third theme is education, which is allowing the youth of today to understand the sacrifices and the tragedy of war. Through that education, we hope that we never have to go down that path and that our young people never have to experience what the people of the generation of the war years had to experience. The fourth and most important theme is legacy, which is leaving a permanent memory in our national history of what the Second World War meant to our community and to the families that make up our community.

Our local Moreton committee has a number of activities proposed on all of these themes. We are also involved in providing assistance through the very important support given by the federal government to other organisations in the electorate who will also be engaging in activities to help commemorate Australia Remembers.

We are particularly excited by the proposal to involve local schools in our community, senior citizens and war veterans in a musical concert. We are going to have a choir of some 600 people. The choir will be made up of primary and secondary school children and senior citizens. They will be singing some of the songs of the war years. It will also involve dances and some of the good big band music of the war years. It promises to be a most exciting event and one that the whole community is looking forward to.

On the theme of legacy, we are dedicating a park in my electorate to the Australia Remembers commemoration. We will have a memorial built in a park in Cracknell Road, Tarragindi which will commemorate the Australia Remembers program. We very much thank the Brisbane City Council and Councillor Mark Bailey for the cooperation and assistance he has provided in enabling us to establish and dedicate that memorial.

We will be having a picnic and concert in Yeronga Park. We will invite the families in the electorate to come along to a lunchtime picnic and concert. We will be very much spreading the message of Australia Remembers. It will be a commemoration but it will also be a celebration of some of the good times and some of the good things that flowed from the war years.

There is going to be an air show at Archerfield airport, which is in my electorate. Bob Taylor, the president of the Sunnybank RSL sub-branch, is very heavily involved in planning that air show. There is going to be an open day and fair at the Yeronga District Military Hospital. We will open up the hospital to the public. On the site of the Yeronga hospital is a heritage home which is more than 110 years old. That is the site of the officers mess. There are a lot of other activities that we will be engaging in during the year. We will draw up a calender of local events which we will distribute to the people in the community to tell them about these activities.

I would like to pay tribute to all the people who will be involved in the Australia Remembers program next year. My particular thanks goes to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and his very able staff who have provided a lot of assistance in our planning and organisation of these events. My commendation goes to him for his foresight in allowing every federal member to be involved in this way. It is a non-partisan issue. It is very much a community issue. I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs has recognised that and provided some very good support. I look forward to next year and the Australia Remembers commemoration.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian National Rail Yards: Site Contamination

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I certainly was not aware until I went to the Speaker's office that while this is being called the adjournment debate, the speakers are taken from the grievance debate list. Perhaps if they went to the whips office it may be straightened out.

PARA.TAB: At present the welfare of the members of my electorate is being jeopardised by yet another of the organisations that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) is responsible for—Australian National. A large number of my Kilburn constituents live close to Australian National's Islington rail yards. For more than 30 years, until the mid-1980s, part of this site was used for the dumping of waste materials. Officially, the material being dumped was asbestos. This was bad enough. However, individuals who worked at the site witnessed repeated dumpings of sulphuric acid, cyanide, pesticides and engine oil in addition to the dumping of asbestos. The dump was finally closed at the insistence of the South Australian Waste Management Commission which found clear evidence that waste had been buried on the site in a manner which did not comply with the requirements of the day.

In the opinion of the Environmental Protection Authority, if the activity had been conducted by a body subject to state law, it is highly likely that a prosecution would have occurred. It was not until the end of last year that Australian National was finally forced to address this danger by engaging Coffey Partners International to assess the site. The anxiety of residents was unduly increased at this time when those assessing the site did so in fully protective clothing while children in light clothing played in the backyards of their homes close by.

The assessment indicated that the soil surrounding the dump had, as feared by the residents, been contaminated. A management plan to deal with this contamination was developed by the consultancy that had undertaken the assessment. South Australia's Environmental Protection Authority approved this plan while regarding it as a temporary fix. AN was to have continuing use of the land and there was no new development planned.

In late November this year, Australian National tendered for remediation works at the site. It is the work that is proposed to be done through this tender that is of major concern to my constituents. My constituent's concerns are shared by the state authorities involved in this matter. I have access to a document, which originated from the Environmental Protection Authority, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Both the Environmental Protection Authority and the South Australian Health Commission are of the view that the tender does not fully reflect the Management plan as approved by the Environmental Protection Authority.
This is an extraordinary conclusion and the reasons for arriving at it are clear. The document states further:

Both the Environmental Protection Authority and the Health Commission have reviewed the tender and believe that it is inadequate in a number of respects: the Management Plan specifies the use of "clean fill" whereas Australian National have proposed to use material with up to 20% contamination with extraneous waste; such action would constitute a breach of the waste management act; levelling of the site using a grader presents an unacceptable risk to residents due to risk of dust arising containing asbestos; problems with dust rising from covered areas throughout the summer; and need to determine the status and material that is removed on site.

Australia National cannot be allowed to proceed with work that may endanger the health of my constituents. If Australian National were privately owned, the state government could force it to adhere to the plan approved by the Environmental Protection Authority. However, since the enterprise concerned is Commonwealth government owned, there is the very real likelihood that Australian National will proceed as it wishes.

PARA.TAB: It has certainly been the case in the past, particularly in relation to state government institutions, that Australian National consult with residents about the management of the dump site. I again refer to the document I quoted which states that the Environmental Protection Authority:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is strongly of the view that Australian National must ensure that local residents are involved more in the process. They have been advised on a number of occasions to begin a consultative process, but for reasons we do not understand they have failed to do so.

I have no intention of allowing the health of the residents in my electorate to be continuingly ignored and jeopardised. I call on the minister to intervene in this case and direct Australian National to adhere fully to the waste management plan approved by the Environmental Protection Authority as would be required by law if Australian National were privately owned and involve my constituents in the management of the dump site that poses such a significant threat to their health.

PARA.TAB: We know that the Minister for Transport has problems on his hands at the moment. We know the noise problems of the third runway are causing him a headache and we know about the air safety problems. My constituents are demanding immediate attention to this problem. While they are residents of South Australia they are also Australians. This is just one example of where laws are in conflict. It is a Commonwealth project involving Commonwealth land and Commonwealth laws apply. I am sure that the members of this House would understand their concerns. There has been a lot of publicity about the proven danger of the asbestos contamination. Cyanide and other poisons have been dumped there in the past. People who worked for AN 30 years ago and leading up to the 1980s continually reported how dangerous that has been. They have personally seen this dumping. One of them is well known to me and I accept what they say. They have the feeling that they are just bumping their heads up against a brick wall.

Contact was made with Senator Collins when he was the minister. He gave verbal assurances that the matter would be fixed, but that has not been the case. A letter later followed with a contrary point of view. The Environmental Protection Authority and the South Australian Health Commission have very real concerns for my constituents. They feel alarmed, they have not been consulted, they do not know what is going on. I call on the minister to intervene and see that their well-being is cared for.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Road Transport Authority in my electorate of Greenway has carried out some roadworks on Richmond Road, Blacktown, which will cause the closure of a service station on the corner of Davis and Richmond Roads. The police officer in charge of the local police and of traffic management agreed that the works proposed would not necessarily have to be carried out. There was a site meeting which the Blacktown Council officers and I attended, along with the mayor, RTA officers and the police. There was total agreement that the work would be left in abeyance until a further meeting was held after discussions with the traffic management control section of the local area.

PARA.TAB: The work has, unfortunately, been carried out. The painting of lines and so on that is being carried out will stop vehicles from both entering and leaving the service station from Richmond Road. I think it is a total disgrace that the council and the RTA have been involved in an event in a local area which would cause the closure of a family run business—run by the one family for about 16 years.

I take the opportunity of wishing all ministers, members, senators, their staff, the staff of the House, Comcar drivers and all those associated with the parliament the very best of Christmas and the new year. I hope that we all come back in 1995 and enjoy a happy year together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few weeks I have been waiting in anticipation for the second tranche of the government's drought relief package. When I watched the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) explain what was in the package, I was first of all disappointed and then amazed at the gall of the Prime Minister, who said in answer to a question from the media that the Labor Party cares for all Australians who find themselves in difficulty. I have news for the Prime Minister and it is all bad.

PARA.TAB: One only has to cross the road out the front of the parliament and talk to Joe Bryant and a few of the farmers that have gathered there in protest to understand that the Prime Minister's statement about caring for all Australians does not wash with them, as I am sure it does not wash with the total farming sector.

If we stop to analyse the package, what do we find? First, we find that the government still has not placed serious drought back into the natural disasters category. This limits the amount of money available for relief because it does not automatically include the federal government, as it used to under the coalition's policy. There was an assistance formerly provided to farmers that enabled the federal government to assist by $4 in aid for every dollar spent by the various state governments. State governments just do not have the resources to cover this terrible drought.

The amount of money pledged by the government of $112 million over the next few years is to complement the $164 million assistance package announced by the government in September. This total over four years of $276 million compares with the $600 million provided by the Fraser government in the approximately one year of the 1982-83 drought.

TALK.START.PARA: —They gave more to the arts than that.

—They certainly have given a great deal. It gives some indication of the non-importance this government places on our rural sector, which not only feeds our nation but also has provided 30 per cent of the raw and processed merchandise export earnings over the last five years. What other impact is the drought having? Economic Insight, put out by the National Farmers Federation, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The . . . effect of the drought is on wheat, other grains and cotton. The lost volume of production this year for these commodities could be in the order of $2750 million or about three quarters of one per cent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP).

Wool production also will be down by about six per cent or $275 million this year. In part this is drought related but it also reflects decisions by farmers . . . to shift out of wool production in response to oversupply and depressed prices.

It also has an effect on the cattle industry and on other industries. The Prime Minister obviously believed that the package announced in September was enough to provide immediate welfare assistance and yesterday's announcement was looking long term. The problem is that unless the government does more by way of immediate assistance there will be many fewer farmers to take up opportunities for the farm management bonds and other assistance that was announced. The taxation incentives are worth nought unless you have money to build up fodder and store water.

PARA.TAB: Landcare projects are to be commended, but many of the farmers I spoke to already have whole farm management plans. They know what has to be done with their properties to obtain that balance between viable production and environmental conservation. What they lack is money. This is as a result of years of low commodity prices, high import costs in a non-deregulated labour market, high tax, high interest rates and a recession this Prime Minister gave them that they had to have but which they certainly did not need.

In addition, farmers who have to compete with very little government assistance in corrupted world markets have seen depreciation allowances cut, tax averaging and income equalisation deposit incentives removed. The introduction of farm management bonds announced yesterday is only replacing something the Prime Minister removed some years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an admission they were wrong originally.

—Exactly. If that scheme introduced by the coalition were in place today, many of the farmers who are on the lawn opposite and many of their colleagues would not be in the position they are in today. I would say that there would be many more farmers still on the land. The ability to write off in one year of expenditure for several on-farm works removed or extended over longer periods was removed. A wine tax was introduced, and more recently the tax benefit for Australian citrus juice has been removed with next to no compensation provided. The fuel freight equalisation scheme was abolished, federal fuel excise has massively increased, the super phosphate bounty was abolished, export inspection charges have been massively increased, wool promotion funding has been cut, primary industry levies have continued to increase and agricultural machine bounties were abolished.

PARA.TAB: As I said before, drought was removed from the natural disaster relief arrangements, livestock valuation tax has increased, the fees for agricultural guarantee fee services have increased, and the LP gas subsidy was abolished. I could go on and on, but time does not permit.

TALK.START.PARA: —More penalties on country people.

—And country towns. You can almost see the country towns shrinking before your eyes. This government has to decide whether it wants the farming sector or not. In my opinion, it has to make up its mind and then move to set up a framework where farmers can look after themselves. Most farmers are independent spirits. They do not want to come cap in hand to governments.

PARA.TAB: There are too many Australians that this government has already robbed of their dignity and has made into welfare recipients when all they wanted to do was work with pride. Nor do farmers want a peasant existence. They want to be in a position where they can make a fair living or go broke, depending on how hard they work and how good their management is. They do not want the present situation to continue where, despite their best efforts, because of government indifference or the government working against them, they cannot survive.

In the short term, the government has to get farmers through the drought. My suggestions are that, first, it ensures that all farmers have some income so that they can feed themselves and their families. Secondly, there must be some form of drought fodder subsidy scheme so that they can keep their herds and flocks together. Thirdly, money must be made available for farmers to plant next season's crops; otherwise, many farmers will not survive.

We all know what is happening to small businesses in rural areas and the effects of the drought, as we know, are not confined to agriculture. We can look through many businesses—chemical machinery suppliers, those who supply consumer goods and services, those at the feedlots and food and fibre processors and so on. This all has an effect on rural areas and, no doubt, will also have an effect on the major capital cities.

Mr Deputy Speaker, time does not permit me to say all I could or should on this matter. As you would know, the farmers and small business people of the Riverina, the electorate I represent, gained nothing immediately out of the government's so-called drought package and also little for the future. There is much I could say about that.

It is to be hoped that the government will act soon to ensure that never again do food parcels such as those being delivered in the electorate of the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb)—I know he has received a lot of feedback from that—have to be distributed to Australian farmers, who have done so much for this nation and from whom we have gained our national ethos.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cat is finally out of the bag. Australia has a high taxing, big spending Liberal state government, and that is the Kennett government in the state of Victoria. I refer honourable members to an article published in the Herald-Sun earlier this week, which confirms something that the Victorian people already know. We have finally pinned the tail on the donkey. The Kennett government is the highest taxing state government in the Commonwealth of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members opposite come into this House and preach ad nauseam to the government of the day that Labor governments are big taxers and big spenders. The proof is in the pudding. At the state level, only one government spends more and taxes more than the Liberal government in New South Wales, and that is the Liberal state government in Victoria. In the electorate of Corio, Geelong residents now pay the equivalent of $2,000 per person to the Kennett government, making it the highest taxing state in the Commonwealth of Australia.

The worst tax of all from this big taxing, big spending Liberal government is the $100 state deficit levy, which the Kennett government is still taking, or robbing, from Geelong residents. One of the most regressive taxes that has ever been introduced by any government at the state or federal level is still in place in the state of Victoria. Honourable members opposite come into this House and talk about low and middle income earners having suffered more under this federal Labor government. It is nothing like the suffering being endured by working families in the state of Victoria today.

Honourable members opposite talk about Labor governments being big spenders. The statistics really show the facts. The Kennett government spending rose some 2.5 per cent in the last year, higher than in the last year of the Kirner government. We could understand if this increased expenditure had gone to health, education and community services, but it has not. It has gone to Jeff Kennett's mates. It has gone to build the casino. We all know how the smelly skunk was pulled across the road there. It has gone to the Grand Prix and to other projects that have been sponsored by Jeff Kennett's mates.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a donkey.

—He is a donkey, and there are a few of them down there. But this is a rich and powerful state that should not be run by donkeys. I thank the honourable member for Werriwa for his interjection. Let us look at the area of health, where the Kennett government has savagely cut into expenditure in Victoria. On a state-wide basis, we have seen $250 million in budget cuts. Hundreds of people have had to wait in trolleys for up to 48 hours for treatment. We have had a higher level of ambulance bypasses, and outpatient services have been slashed.

PARA.TAB: I would like to recount to honourable members a phone call I received the other day from a constituent—an elderly gentleman who pleaded with me to make a representation to the Geelong hospital and to the state Liberal member, Marie Tehan. Do you know what the problem was? His 70-year-old wife slipped over one Saturday morning and was taken to the hospital at 9.15. She saw a doctor at 11.15. That particular young woman was very compassionate but very hard worked in the outpatients' area on the weekend. It took some seven hours for a 70-year-old woman to receive treatment in a public hospital in Geelong.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long?

—Seven hours for a 70-year-old woman to receive treatment in the Geelong hospital. That has nothing to do with the competency, efficiency or compassionate nature of the staff because they were all of that. The simple fact is that the hospital is under-resourced. Let me quote what has happened to the Geelong hospital under the Kennett government.

PARA.TAB: The state government has reduced its grants by five per cent in 1993-94 and by 2.7 per cent this financial year. The hospital does not have the funds to cope with current demand and is struggling with significant budget restraints. That is according to the chief executive, Mr Phil Sheedy, who made that statement in November this year. The hospital slashed 200 jobs last year, and that was due to the budget cuts of the Kennett government. As quickly as we create the jobs at the federal level, they pull them out at the state level. Then they come to me bleating about the fact that the Geelong economy is not growing.

I will give some other examples of how this state government is ripping the insides out of my electorate. The Geelong hospital has one of Victoria's longest waiting lists. Bed capacity at the hospital has been capped at 400, 30 fewer than the maximum that has been set. This is from a high taxing, high debt, big spending Liberal government, yet honourable members opposite come into this House and lecture us about fiscal management.
Mr Abbott interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the honourable member opposite makes that small interjection. The Kennett government looks after its mates but it also looks after the bureaucracy. It has spent $35,000 on a weekend retreat for senior health bureaucrats in Queenscliff—$35,000 for a weekend down at Queenscliff, walking around the tourist shops, having a seminar, coming up with a few conclusions about how they have wrecked the state health system in Victoria.
—It is a shame.

—It is a crying shame what is happening to my electorate. Let me just canvass education. Eight thousand teachers have been sacked in the state of Victoria. The great competitive advantage of this state is being ripped and torn by a Liberal government that has its priorities wrong. It has cut half a billion dollars from the state education budget, sacked 3,500 cleaners, closed down 250 schools and school support centres.

PARA.TAB: At the Geelong level, we once had one of the best educational infrastructures in the state, but this is what has happened to the region that I represent in this parliament. They have closed the institute of educational administration. It was flogged off—a public asset, on public land—to the private sector for a song so that it could satisfy some ideological obsession by the bureaucrats running the state education department in Victoria.

They sacked 260 teachers and three school support centres have been closed. What has been the result of that in the electorate of Corio? We have seen increases in class sizes. Almost one in three state school students in the Barwon south-western region will leave before finishing year 12—one of Victoria's worst retention rates, one of Victoria's worst results. Three Geelong schools have recently been asked to explain compulsory fees which they are imposing to try to counter the cuts in state funding.

In the Geelong Advertiser of 1 November 1944, the Geelong school principals warned that local primary schools could soon be unable to provide quality education due to the state government schools of the future program. Once again, we go back to the future when the Liberals gain the treasury bench; back to the future federally and at the state level. We have seen reductions in subject choices and less time for teacher preparation. We have seen an increase in truancy due to the loss of state school support centres. The architect of the chaos and confusion will not even come into the region to debate these very important issues.

As far as transport is concerned, the Liberal government is going to flog off and disaggregate one of Geelong's prime infrastructure assets, the Port of Geelong. That has been opposed by the business community. It has been opposed by the general community, and I have a steady stream of Liberal Party members in the business community asking me to attack the state government for what it is doing to the Port of Geelong. In contrast, the state government in the One Nation document allocated resources to put the standard gauge through Geelong and link this city irrevocably to economic developments in the rest of the nation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is not the third runway as such but the bungled way in which the third runway has been brought into operation. When Wal Fife first proposed a third runway, it was supposed to mean more take-offs and landings over Botany Bay. A third runway was supposed to mean that there would be more flights in and out of Sydney and fewer houses affected by noise. Unfortunately, this government's third runway has meant fewer flights and more noise. It has had the very opposite effect of the third runway that was first proposed by Wal Fife back in 1982. This government's third runway has meant that hundreds of flights which used to take off over Botany Bay are now taking off over Marrickville and the inner west. Thousands of homes which never suffered from aircraft noise, or which suffered only minimally, are now suffering from deafening aircraft noise 50 times an hour.

PARA.TAB: The result of this government's third runway has been that total aircraft movements at Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport have reduced from 64 an hour to 50 an hour. Of Ansett Airline's flights in and out of Sydney, 91 per cent are now subject to delay. Ansett has received 30,000 complaints about these delays in a single day since the introduction of the so-called third runway. The government has spent $200 million to make a bad situation worse. Gee thanks, Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and Prime Minister (Mr Keating), for making the lives of so many Sydneysiders miserable! Under the administration of this government, this third runway is going to end up the most expensive fishing pier in Sydney, because all it is good for is for people to stand on the edge and to throw a fishing line into Botany Bay.

The problem with the third runway has been politics, from start to finish. In the beginning the Prime Minister decided that, if we were going to have a third runway, he must close down the east-west runway. Why? So that the noise problems would be transferred from marginal Labor seats to safe Labor seats where, he reasoned, it would not do so much damage. Now that the whole thing has blown up beyond control, he wants to transfer the noise problem from Labor seats to Liberal seats. We have all heard of that classic political exercise—the gerrymander—where votes are transferred from inconvenient to convenient areas. This government has given us a new mander, the `noisemander', where noise is transferred from inconvenient to convenient areas—in other words, from Labor to Liberal electorates.

Complaints from all over Sydney have been coming to members of this House over the last few weeks. In my own electorate, I have had complaints from the residents of Mosman, Manly Vale, Balgowlah and many other places. Dozens, if not hundreds, of complaints have come from people who have a right to expect that the ordinary amenities of life will not be disturbed by bungled government decision making.

I am not speaking just for the electorate of Warringah, I am speaking for the whole of Sydney, and I am saying what members opposite would like to say about this decision if they were not dumb struck by the Stalinist discipline that the Labor Party puts on to its members.

It is interesting that, when the Minister for Transport came into this House on Wednesday and tried to defend his policy, the faces of members opposite were embarrassed, ashamed and crestfallen as the Minister for Transport and then the Prime Minister twisted and prevaricated trying to defend the indefensible and justify the unjustifiable. They know that what this government has done is sell out Labor values and sell out Labor voters.

The government has come up with a noise amelioration policy, but it is too little too late. All the government has done is come up with a little earmuff money. But the people of Sydney do not want earmuff money; they want a restoration of the quality of life that they enjoyed before.

A fundamental principle of justice is that no-one can take away the conditions that people have been living with. No-one can take away the rights that people have come to expect. This government has quite simply gone in and taken away the level of enjoyment that people in so many parts of Sydney had come to take for granted. This government must close down the third runway. It must be closed down now, and it must stay shut until such time as the new control tower is built, new radar systems are in place and the third runway can be a benefit and not a blight to the ordinary people of Sydney.

The real villain in all this is the Prime Minister: first, because he introduced shabby and grubby politics into the original decision making; second, because he is quite happy to spend $150 million, or offer $150 million, to tear down the Cahill Expressway—a perfectly functioning piece of transport infrastructure; he is quite happy to give his $250 million gift to the arts community, but he is not prepared to spend the money necessary to put the third runway into an immediately functioning condition—and, third, because, yet again, he is protecting his mate Laurie Brereton.

The Prime Minister has been indebted to the Minister for Transport ever since the minister made the most famous Lambretta ride in history. That was the night when the Minister for Transport roared off on his Lambretta to drag Lindsay North out of bed in his pyjamas over to the balloting booths of Blaxland so that the boxes could be impounded and taken back to head office. That was a usual right wing rort practice to ensure that the Prime Minister ended up as the member for Blaxland—the sort of thing that Tom Burns of the Queensland Right said was a typical slimy, mongrel act of the New South Wales right.

The Prime Minister may have protected his mate once too often. It is important for the Prime Minister to remember that the Minister for Transport in a previous incarnation was the main player in bringing down the Unsworth government. He has destroyed Unsworth Labor and, with this insanity over the third runway, he is doing his best to destroy Carr Labor; and it is by no means impossible that he will not play a big part in destroying Keating Labor. The minister for monuments, the minister for chaos, might have as his ultimate monument the destruction of the Keating Labor government. When it comes to making life difficult for the Labor Party, Laurie is part of a family business at the moment. There is Laurie and Deidre—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Warringah will refer to members by their correct title. Once you get away with it, twice you do not.

—I take correction, Mr Speaker. There is the former minister in the New South Wales government and the current Minister for Transport. The name Brereton must be one name that Bob Carr wishes just now he had never heard. The Minister for Transport said in this parliament on Wednesday, `I take full responsibility for ANL.' He ought to face up to his responsibility for this bungle over Sydney airport and resign. He ought to take the same responsibility for the CAA and for Sydney airport that he offered to take for ANL.

PARA.TAB: It is not really surprising that the Minister for Transport is not interested in living with the consequences of his action. It is not surprising that the minister is trying to run away from this mess that he has created at Sydney airport because, quite frankly, it is all of a piece for his behaviour. At the same time that the people in the minister's own electorate are suffering from noises, what should be happening? The minister is renovating his beach house at Palm Beach. It is interesting that Labor members rush off to traditional Labor areas when they want a safe seat, but they rush off to Liberal areas when they want a nice house. It is typical of the hypocrisy opposite.I conclude by quoting Robin Powell of Haberfield who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Let's finally have some honesty about the third runway. It's not a third runway at all, unless the east-west runway is reopened to share the load, and its lunatic operations are making hundreds of thousands of lives a misery.
Here! Here! Robin Powell, you are right. It is about time that this government realised what it is doing to the people of Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott) has dreams about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), because he cannot finish a speech in this House without living out his obsession with the Prime Minister. He dreams of the Prime Minister and points of order. It is no wonder he wakes up in a hot sweat. I will not in this adjournment debate be talking about the young royalist, but rather addressing my remarks to the ageing Marxist—the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary).

PARA.TAB: Recently my attention was drawn to remarks made in this place by the member for Wills which were directed at my support for free trade in APEC and national competition policies throughout the Australian economy. Let me respond. The member for Wills reached his intellectual peak as a football coach. He should have stayed there. In this House he represents the politics of the 1950s. He is as much yesterday's man as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), but instead of a white picket fence, the member for Wills represents an old, dilapidated fence—an old, dilapidated, broken ideology of clapped-out Marxism. By the standards of Australian politics in the 1990s, the member for Wills is back to the future—back to the future with fortress Australia, tariff protection all around, centralised wage fixing and a monocultural ethnic base, all underscored by the burnt out, clapped out Marxist notion that the only good capital is public capital.

The member for Wills takes the luxury in this House of issuing a plague on both sides of the House, but with little scrutiny of his own contribution. My purpose on this adjournment debate is to redress that imbalance and to ask some questions. Why does the member for Wills not like competition? Why does he not want to see competition in the public and private sectors produce benefits for consumers in his electorate? Working class consumers in his electorate would be denied benefits by the member for Wills because he does not want capital to compete. He does not want markets to work. He wants to go back to the failed policies of eastern Europe where you lock away markets and you lock away capital in the hands of public monopolies. He does not want capital to work, he does not want capital to compete. He stands for monopoly markets and higher prices for working class consumers in the electorate of Wills.

Further, he stands for high tariffs—back to the 1950s with high tariffs. He is a replay of Black Jack McEwen. High tariffs potentially represent the biggest regressive tax that any politician in this country could advocate—bigger than the 15 per cent GST. The tariff walls as advocated by the member for Wills would hurt working class consumers in his electorate more substantially than any of the policies that the Liberal and National parties could inflict upon the people of Australia. He stands for high, regressive taxes whenever he calls for a return to high tariff protection in Australia.

The member for Wills should understand a little recent economic history. He should understand the substantial benefits enjoyed by consumers all over the country from this government's introduction of competition policies. By ending the two-airline agreement, airfares fell by 20 per cent from September 1990 to September 1993. There have been benefits to the consumers—and I am sure many of them living in the electorate of Wills—of $100 million per annum.

With the advent of competition from Optus, Telecom prices have fallen by four per cent between capital cities, and the peak call rates between Sydney and Melbourne—including the electorate of Wills—fell by 20 per cent between June 1992 and May 1993. Consumers in his electorate are 20 per cent better off on the cost of their calls to Sydney because of this government's policy of competition on telephones. There has been an 11 per cent fall in the cost of overseas calls and a nine per cent fall in the cost of mobile telephone calls.

Further, deregulation of egg production and marketing in New South Wales, as an example, has produced a decrease in average retail prices of 38c per dozen, with savings to consumers of $21 million per annum. They are the sorts of consumer benefits enjoyed by working class people that the member for Wills will not endorse. He wants to go to higher prices, public monopolies and monopoly markets. The deregulation of third party compulsory insurance in my own state of New South Wales resulted in premiums falling from $350 in 1989 to $190 in 1993.

The government, as you would be aware, Mr Speaker, has a broad agenda for national competition policies through COAG and the Hilmer report. It places up for grabs the $8.2 billion in government business enterprise dividends—federal and state—that flow back into government budgets. Through competition exposing these public monopolies to market forces, $8.2 billion is potentially available for the benefit of consumers. If the member for Wills looked after the interests of his working class consumers, he would certainly be supporting competition so that the $8.2 billion does not go into the coffers of government, it goes into the pockets of people who need it most—the people who consume water, gas, electricity; the people who make telephone calls and undertake airline movements across Australia.

Overall, competition produces lower prices, better services, greater market choice and, with overall efficiency improvements, greater investment and more employment all round. Ultimately, the member for Wills stands for the Albanian economic model of locking the country behind tariff walls, locking out migrants, locking out competition and locking out market forces. He is, in the Australian parliament, the Albanian finance minister. He should go to Albania and see the sort of damage that his policies and his model have caused in that nation. It should not happen here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your model is Central America.

—It is a funny thing about politics, if you go far enough around to the right where the member for Kennedy sits and far enough around on the left where the member for Wills sits, they come together. They sit over there together, basically sharing the same views about Australia: to lock out the migrants, lock out the ideas, lock out the competition, and put this country back to the status of fortress Australia. It is ideological convergence. They are suited to be sitting next to each other in this parliament. Worse than that, as it is pointed out in this parliament—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I claim to be misrepresented.
—No, this is not the time for that.
—He claimed that I was against migration. I was the migration minister in Queensland and I advocated a level of 350,000 a year.
—You might get your chance to respond in a minute.

—It must have been a big responsibility as migration minister in a state parliament, when the constitution says that only this parliament has responsibility for migration powers. The member must have had a big staff and big agenda—the world's first state migration minister.

PARA.TAB: It is frequently pointed out in this parliament that the member for Wills is a Labor rat. It is pointed out by people on the other side of the House, by the Prime Minister, and by members all around this place. He is Billy Hughes with a beard. Worse than that, he is a class traitor. He has deceived and betrayed his own class by his support for higher prices, higher taxes, higher regressive taxes through tariff walls.

He is in this place for one reason. He is in this place until the next election for one reason: the voting preference of Liberals in the electorate of Wills. He gets the Liberal preferences in that electorate that allow him to sit in this parliament until the next election. He is put in this place by tories voting Liberal 1, Cleary 2 in the electorate of Wills. He panlicks those tories in his electorate every day. He has betrayed his class, he has betrayed all the interests that are true to the great cause of Labor. I certainly look forward to Kelvin Thomson, the newly endorsed ALP candidate for Wills, putting an end to this betrayal, to this sham, and sending the member for Wills back to where he belongs—Albania.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to speak for the third time this week on the third runway. On this occasion people on the other side are saying `Oh no'; if they listened to my speech, they might be pleased with what I have to say.
—I will listen.

—I know you will, Janice. Before I say this, I have to correct the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott). He completely misrepresented me during his speech. How was he to know that I have had over 35 years association with people who have suffered from brain damage after an accident of any sort, with people who have a congenital defect which causes brain difficulties? More importantly, he was not to know that I have been closely associated with the world of rehabilitation for the last 40 years, and I am very pleased to hear that the member for Gilmore is now on side in this tremendously important area. I trust he will now continue to show his interest and concern in this field of stimulating, if heartbreaking, activity.

PARA.TAB: It was not part of my plan, but in view of the narrowness of the member's speech, I take this opportunity to pay tremendous tribute to all those selfless people who have worked for a very long time, most of them for all their lives, rehabilitating people who have been gravely injured either at birth or in an accident. This is a matter that has been part of my inner soul for 40 years or more and I resent a new member in this House suggesting that I would laugh at anybody who has brain damage. All my life I have been associated with the rehabilitation of brain damaged people in this community.

I hope the member's speech will inspire even more people in this House to realise that rehabilitation is not a part-time activity. It is not an easy activity and it is not something about which you go away and say, `God, I must try to help them,' and forget about it for the next month, year or 10 years or whatever. Rehabilitation means daily constant care and consideration by a very large number of people.

The member for Gilmore talked about people being damaged in car accidents. It is horrendous. People who live after a car smash can have no brain left at all. This happens on a regular basis. It needs compassion; it does not need political statements or party politics. I resent the way the member for Gilmore spoke during his speech today. I had no intention of raising this subject again today, but I feel it has to be raised, not just for me or for the people concerned, but for the huge number of people who have been injured.

For quadriplegics and paraplegics, the situation can be even worse. Very often brain damaged people are not aware. Their brains have gone but their carers, with great persistence and under difficult circumstances, can assist them to live a very happy life. Their brains are not functioning and they do not know what they do not know. If we are going to talk about the rehabilitation needs of this country, the speeches in this place should be speeches of compassion and not of party politics at any level. It is beyond and above all those considerations.

However, I did not get up to speak on that; I got up to speak about the map on the front page of the Telegraph Mirror today. Although it is not going to win my football team any marks, I am delighted to see that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) took note of my speech two nights ago in this House when I told him he could solve the problems of southern take-offs from the third, first or any runway if the planes avoided flying over Kurnell. On Tuesday night I said that, for the first time ever, Kurnell was being flown over at 800 feet and that as a safety matter Kurnell oil refinery was being flown over by 800 feet.

I see in the paper today—I have not been able to read the full details—the map showing exactly what I asked the minister to do, and I thank him for that. The minister and I—I do not boast about this—happen to be political neighbours. I share with him his very sincere concerns about Botany Bay and the people living around it.

I have not read the details, so I do not know when it is going to start, but a lot of people in Kurnell—1,800 voters in fact, ignoring the very many small children they have—will be sleeping soundly tonight. I say to the Minister for Transport: thank you for doing what you have done for the people of my electorate. My heart goes out to the people west of Sydney airport. I do not know what can be done for them. For the 112 houses, this will solve nothing. I have lived under an aircraft path and I know that you become very sensitive to it. It is no use saying they have known for four years and they bought houses. That is nonsense. Nobody can understand the noise of a plane flying above them until they have experienced it themselves.

I do not know what the solution for Sydney is going to be. Close or open the third runway—I do not know. All I know is that I am going to my godson's wedding on 17 December in Adelaide and I am having to come to Canberra the night before to fly to Adelaide because of the blockades being run by Marrickville Council on that date. I do not know if I would have used those tactics, but I wish the council well in its attempts to obtain relief for those areas west of the airport in Sydney.

As I said here three nights ago, as I have said to meetings in Kurnell and as I have said in my letters to every person in Kurnell for the last two weeks, the decision on the runway was not made by FAC or CAA; it was made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Transport. I do not like to see the bad naming we have seen here this afternoon. Goodness knows why the poor member for Wills (Mr Cleary) was attacked in that way. I believe you do not achieve anything in this parliament by bad naming anybody. I have kept to that view for 28 years and I will continue to keep to it. But the fact that the Minister for Transport was able to change the flight paths over my electorate has confirmed what I have been saying for the last two or three weeks, and that is that the decision to open runways on 4 November in Botany Bay was not a FAC or a CAA request. It was a very stupid and reckless political decision, but a political decision it was. I am afraid that, if the coat fits, they have to wear it.
