They will not hear me criticising what they are trying to do about the problems for Sydney. They have not heard me criticising for the last three weeks what they are trying to do in Sydney. I am very grateful that the cabinet took note of my representations and returned the flights from the Sutherland shire over the sandhills and through the heads of Botany Bay.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: University of Wollongong: Retirement of Vice-Chancellor

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I am particularly pleased that you are occupying the chair for this speech because we are neighbours and represent seats in the Illawarra. I know that the University of Wollongong is in your electorate of Cunningham, but a lot of the students come from my electorate of Throsby—indeed, the staff of the university are spread all over the Illawarra—and had we not both been detained here today, we would have been part of a large group at the University of Wollongong to say farewell to Professor Ken McKinnon, the Vice-Chancellor for 13 years.

PARA.TAB: Ken McKinnon took over from Professor Michael Birt as Vice-Chancellor of the University of Wollongong in August 1981. At that time the university student body was around 3,000. He brought with him a freshness of approach and an enthusiasm for the University of Wollongong and over the years has taken it to an international standard. You, Mr Speaker, not only as a former student, but also as a lecturer at that university, would know of the tremendous advances that have been made over the last couple of years.

As well as expanding the university to accommodate from about 3,000 students to over 11,000 at present, Ken McKinnon has attracted outstanding scholars to the university, has given it an international reputation and has made important international contacts, especially with China and Thailand. He came to the University of Wollongong after a long and distinguished career of 20 years in Papua New Guinea where he rose to the position of Director-General of education. Following this, he was appointed by Gough Whitlam, the then Prime Minister, to the chair of the Commonwealth Schools Commission here in Canberra.

Given his national contacts and international standing, I thought some time ago that he may have taken up a permanent position with UNESCO, to which he has had a long commitment, having been the chair of the Australian Council for UNESCO from 1984 to 1988. He would have made an outstanding contribution to the work of UNESCO but Wollongong was the beneficiary when he did not apply for the UNESCO position.

At the time of his appointment as vice-chancellor, I was a member of the council of the University of Wollongong and had a close working relationship with Ken McKinnon. I was a member of the council of the university for some six years until the then Liberal Minister for Education in New South Wales, one Terry Metherell, decided for reasons best known to himself not to reappoint me to that position.

Ken McKinnon has devoted his life to education. He has brought great distinction to the University of Wollongong and has many friends nationally and internationally. I hope that, in his retirement from the position of vice-chancellor, the educational world will continue to benefit from his great expertise. We wish Ken McKinnon well in his retirement and I am sure it will be a very full retirement.

Ken McKinnon has served the University of Wollongong and the Illawarra well. As you would be aware, Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was present at the University of Wollongong only last week with both of us and he was very impressed with what had been achieved and what was still being achieved there. I am sure the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) would also agree because he also covers that area and would be very familiar with the work and the distinction that Ken McKinnon has brought to that university.

The new vice-chancellor will be Gerard Sutton, who is the present deputy vice-chancellor, a very distinguished international scholar. I am sure he will continue to bring the distinction to the University of Wollongong that Ken McKinnon has over the past years that he has been vice-chancellor there. I thank the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the Australian meat industry, and in particular our beef producers, have had a rough ride of late. With drought, residue scares and meatworks strikes, the industry has never had a more horrendous time. There are genuine concerns about the effects on exports, but what we have in central Queensland at present is a totally different circumstance. The beef industry has also been hamstrung over recent times by the lack of effective reform in meat processing and other related sectors, which is reducing the competitiveness of this great industry and its product.

PARA.TAB: This fundamental problem was best highlighted this week with the discovery of cheap imported American beef being sold over the counter in central Queensland, in the very heartland of the nation's biggest beef producing region. It is said that approximately 25 per cent of Australia's beef is produced within 250 or 300 kilometres of Rockhampton. I was first alerted to the situation by a Rockhampton grazier, who contacted me about cheap American rumps being supplied to the local Angliss butcher shop at North Rockhampton.

Angliss advised that it did receive two cartons of American rumps from its meat supplier, Mackay based processor Thomas Borthwicks and Sons. Angliss has stressed that none of the meat was sold and that the product was returned. A Borthwicks spokesman confirmed that the company had purchased an undisclosed quantity of American rumps from a southern importer and that those rumps were being sold to other meat wholesalers and retailers in central Queensland.

The spokesman said the imported rumps were purchased because of a shortage of suitable domestic trade cattle as a result of the drought. Irrespective of whether the right type of cattle was available or not, we must accept that imports occur from time to time, though I suspect in this particular circumstance they were not being brought into a niche market or for the restaurant trade but simply to be sold alongside Australian meat in Australian butcher shops. In 1993-94 Australia, which is predominantly a net exporter, imported 5,600 tonnes, worth some $22 million, mostly from New Zealand.

However, what disturbs me is that, like the recent Sizzler beef import case, this foreign beef can be landed in this country for less than the cost of the home grown product. I have been informed that chilled cryovac rumps from the United States that appeared in central Queensland this week were landed in Melbourne for $4.70 per kilogram. Yet the same locally grown rump produced from a Rockhampton abattoir is sold for $5.40 per kilogram—a difference of 70c per kilogram between the local and imported product. Even allowing 20c a kilogram for freight from Melbourne to Rockhampton, it is still 50c a kilogram cheaper than the Australian product.

Whether you agree with the trading practices of meat suppliers is not the question. Certainly I am not interested in any calls for boycotts of the companies involved. I accept in good grace, as do most members of the National Party, that we have become a signatory to GATT, that we are moving into APEC, and that for that reason boycotts would be inappropriate. My concern is that American beef can be landed in this country for less than the home grown product.

As the shadow minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson), has said, it is staggering that an Australian beef importer can buy American cattle at prices 60 per cent higher than those paid in Australia, process the beef in American abattoirs, transport it to the seaboard and across US wharves, ship it across the Pacific, move it across our notoriously expensive waterfront, distribute it in Australia and still sell it for less than the Australian home grown product.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's subsidised, you donkey.
—Listen, if it is subsidised and your government is aware of the subsidising, what is your Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) doing about an action against the US?
—What about dumping duties?
—Exactly. What have you been doing about the dumping duties?
—Through the chair, if you don't mind.

—Yes. I will address through the chair. It is a great admission. It is one thing to be derelict about the runways at Sydney airport, but it is another thing to be derelict about dumping at a time when the Australian beef industry has probably been under the worst challenge not only from imports but also from the most horrendous drought we have ever had. My colleague might do well to be a little more compassionate and sensitive to the needs of these people.

PARA.TAB: Quite simply, our meat processing costs are too high. A recent study into the productivity and efficiency of the Australian meat industry, prepared for the NFF by AACM International Consultants, found that the total costs of export cattle abattoir operations are approximately 70 per cent above those in the United States. It costs $A46 per head to process a head of beef in the USA and $A102 per head to process the same carcass in Australia.

Take the recent Industry Commission report into the meat industry. It pointed out that the inferior and overregulated industrial relations system is the principal cause of our industry's inefficiencies. The problem with the system is simply that it does not encourage employers and employees to get together and reform work practices, improve productivity and increase real wages. Of course, the costs of all these inefficiencies are passed down the chain to the beef producer who is at the bottom of the chain. The producer has nowhere to pass on his costs. The beef producer must carry the burden of the higher processing costs, outdated abattoir work practices, excessive transport and shipping costs and rising government taxes and inspection charges which we have heard about all too often in this chamber.

Surely there is a message in this beef import saga in Rockhampton. It is perhaps just the tip of the iceberg. We have seen what has happened to the Australian pork industry by not being sufficiently vigilant about imports into this country and by not taking action against those imports on the basis of dumping. If the government were half fair dinkum, it would be doing something about it. As I said, there is a message in this import saga for the government, the trade union movement and our meat industry as a whole. It should be a catalyst for reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I rush into speaking this afternoon, I would first take this opportunity, Mr Speaker, to commend you on the manner in which you have been able to hold order in this House during the term of the parliament this year. I suggest that you have done a very good job, at times under extreme circumstances.

PARA.TAB: As a new member of parliament, I have been trying to gain some understanding of the standing and sessional orders of this place. I am amazed at how continuously they are defied in this House. Today I opened Standing and Sessional Orders to page 19 and looked at the orders pertaining to the rules of debate and privilege. It was not long before I discovered three out of seven that are constantly flouted here in this House. Standing order No. 55, for example, states:
When a Member is speaking, no Member may converse aloud or make any noise or disturbance to interrupt the Member.

SPEECH.PARA: For goodness sake! That goes on constantly in this chamber. It is rude, obnoxious and really should not be allowed. Mr Speaker, you do a terrific job in trying to stop it. I might suggest also that it comes not only from the opposite side of the House, although a greater amount comes from there. Standing order No. 56 is interesting. It states:

PARA.TAB: Every Member shall make obeisance to the Chair in passing to or from his or her seat.

SPEECH.PARA: On one day during the sittings this week, I counted nine persons leave this House and some re-enter, without even addressing the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including the Prime Minister.
—I am not saying anyone who was included, but I can suggest to the honourable member who interjects it came constantly from the opposite side of the House.

PARA.TAB: The other rule that is flouted constantly is when every member comes into the House:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he or she . . . shall take his or her seat, and shall not at any time stand in any of the passages or gangways.
That standing order is absolutely and constantly ignored. Nobody on the other side thinks about that particular standing order. Mr Speaker, I ask that members of the House consider—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Leo?
—Order! The honourable member for Fisher! The honourable member for Bass is being extremely helpful to the chair this afternoon.

—It is a change, I do say, I suppose. I suggest that all members of this House stop and remember that they are representatives of their community in the parliament of Australia. This House is often on the television and those sorts of things are often picked up. The young generation, whom we are trying to educate on what this parliament is all about, must be looking not only in wonder but also in horror at some of the actions and behaviour in here. I do ask that all members think about the standing orders that we are asked to look to and uphold. We are Australia; millions of people look to us for guidance in every respect. That is where we start. The other standing order I would talk of—
—Standing order 145.

—That is it exactly. The honourable member for Prospect tells me section 145—and that is another standing order which I have marked out. I have never heard so much irrelevant rubbish as that spoken in this place by members of this House—
—By ministers.

—including the member opposite. I have never heard so much rubbish as that which comes out of the mouth of the member opposite. Where do these members come from? They do not even know what they are talking about. Mr Speaker, once again I would ask everyone to look at the standing and sessional orders, as set down by the parliament of Australia, and obey them.
